While it might make a slight difference to viewers' perceptions of Grant, it's hardly a historical travesty on the level of, say, {setting a film in the wrong era with the wrong people}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/nov/06/periodandhistorical-melgibson"> (Apocalypto), {attributing a major wartime breakthrough to the wrong nation}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/feb/25/u-571-reel-history"> (U-571) or viciously {slandering everyone in the 16th century}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/nov/03/anonymous-shakespeare-reel-history"> (Anonymous).

Violence
The film builds towards its crucial final scene at Fruitvale Station. There is a fight on the train, and the BART police arrive. Though the events on the platform were filmed by several people present, the exact details remain controversial – and the film does not use the real names of the police officers involved. {One video}<hyperlink="http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Video-shows-another-BART-cop-hitting-passenger-3175189.php"> has been said to show an officer striking one of the detained men, identified by some as Grant; the officer's attorney {disputed that analysis.}<hyperlink="http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Protesters-Push-for-Charges-Against-Second-BART-Police-Officer.html"> Grant was shot in the back by Officer Johannes Mehserle. Mehserle's defence argued that he mistook his gun for his taser. The jury convicted him of involuntary manslaughter – a lesser charge than the second-degree murder or voluntary manslaughter options that the judge had also offered. The film depicts the scene as confusing. Its focus is on the impact on Grant's family and friends, not on what the officers thought or did.

Verdict
{Fruitvale Station}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/fruitvale-station"> is a fair portrait of Oscar Grant's story, and a brilliant portrait of how lack of opportunity, routine incarceration and racism conspire to devalue the lives of young black men in America.
TheShitBetween: This brilliant film sticks closely to the known facts about one unlawful killing in 2009, but is part of a wider, ever relevant story about the treatment of young black men in America

Title: James Risen calls Obama 'greatest enemy of press freedom in a generation'
Author: Joanna Walters
ArticleText:
The New York Times reporter {James Risen, who faces jail}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/13/obama-administration-jail-james-risen"> over his refusal to reveal a source and testify against a former CIA agent accused of leaking secrets, has called President Barack Obama “the greatest enemy of press freedom in a generation”.

{Speaking to his colleague Maureen Dowd,}<hyperlink="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/17/opinion/sunday/maureen-dowd-wheres-the-justice-at-justice.html?_r=0"> Risen accused the president of aggressively pursuing journalists, including himself, who report sensitive stories that reflect poorly on the US government.

Risen faces jail over his reporting of a botched intelligence operation that ended up spilling nuclear secrets to Iran. The Justice Department has long been seeking to force him to testify and name the confidential source of the account, which is contained in his 2006 book State of War.

Risen recently failed in an attempt to have {the supreme court}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/law/2014/jun/02/supreme-court-declines-review-reporter-james-risen-source-nyt"> review an order for him to testify, and acknowledges that he has exhausted all his legal options against the Justice Department’s pursuit of him under the controversial Espionage Act. In the face of incarceration that could come as early as this autumn, he is resorting instead to journalistic defiance.

Risen would be the first journalist to go to prison for failing to divulge sources since 2005, when the former New York Times reporter Judith Miller was {jailed for contempt of court,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/jul/07/pressandpublishing.usnews"> after refusing to testify about a source before a federal grand jury.

“I was nervous for a long time, but they’ve been after me for six years so now I try to ignore it,” Risen told Dowd.

The pursuit of Risen began under the administration of President George W Bush. The Justice Department tried to prosecute him under the {Espionage}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/espionage"> Act for his 2006 Pulitzer Prize-winning scoop about the illegal wiretapping of American citizens after the terrorist attacks of 11 September 2001. It also targeted him for the revelations in State of War.

The Bush administration arrested Jeffrey Sterling, whom Dowd on Sunday referred to as a “disillusioned” former CIA operative, and accused him of being the source of Risen’s leak about Iran. The {Obama administration}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/obama-administration"> continues to attempt to force Risen to testify against Sterling and name him as his main source.

Risen is furious at statements from the likes of Obama and the attorney general, Eric Holder, about supporting press freedom – including condemnation of the police in Ferguson, Missouri, for this week {arresting journalists reporting on riots there.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/14/obama-ferguson-police-excessive-force-michael-brown">

Obama and Holder said journalists should not be arrested or harassed for doing their jobs and covering “a story that needs to be told”. In May, Holder said of the Sterling case: “No reporter who is doing his job is going to go to jail.” Risen, however, could be behind bars within weeks.

Dowd asked Risen how the Obama administration could use the Espionage Act to imprison reporters and whistleblowers while not acting on the acknowledged {use of torture by the CIA on terrorism suspects}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/01/obama-cia-torture-some-folks-brennan-spying"> and the same agency spying on the US Senate.

“It’s hypocritical,” Risen said. “A lot of people still think this is some kind of game or signal or spin. They don’t want to believe that Obama wants to crack down on the press and whistleblowers. But he does. He’s the greatest enemy to press freedom in a generation.”

Last week, groups campaigning for press freedom handed a petition with more than 100,000 signatures to the Justice Department, urging it to drop the case against Risen.

“It’s surreal to be caught up in a news story instead of writing about one,” he told Dowd.
TheShitBetween:
• Journalist refuses to reveal source of story about CIA operation
• President’s support for press freedom called ‘hypocritical’

Title: Israeli ship remains at sea as thousands of protesters gather in Oakland
Author: Rebecca Bowe
ArticleText:
An Israeli ship subject of a pro-Palestinian protest has docked, but demonstrations at the port of Oakland in {California}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/california"> continue after between 2,000 and 3,000 pro-Palestinian activists streamed towards the port entrance on Saturday, chanting and waving flags. It remains unclear whether the ship’s cargo has been unloaded.

The protesters intended to form a picket line to prevent work crews from unloading the ship.

Activists had originally planned to meet at 5am for a blockade of the Zim Integrated Shipping Services vessel, but word that its arrival had been delayed prompted organisers to push the protest back until later in the afternoon.

The event began with a brief rally at a nearby transit station, folowed by a march to the port. Sameh Ayesh, a 21-year-old Palestinian activist with the San Francisco-based Arab Youth Organisation, led the crowd in a chant.

“We’re gonna block the boat,” he called into a megaphone. “Block, block the boat.”

But before the march had even reached the port entrance, an activist who identified himself as Eyad delivered word that the Zim vessel would not be docking that day. An online ship tracking service showed that the vessel was off the coast of California, closer to Santa Cruz, as the march got under way.

Activists interpreted the delay as a victory, viewing the schedule as having been made in response to the planned pickets. “We have stopped the Zim Piraeus from docking on the west coast of the United States,” said Eyad, of the Arab Resource and Organising Center (Aroc), into a megaphone, drawing cheers from the crowd as the march came to a halt on a bridge leading towards the docks.

A spokeswoman for the pot of Oakland, Marilyn Sandifur, declined to comment on the protest but disputed the Guardian's estimate of crowd numbers, saying that the port and local police believed the figure to be closer to 500. Zim, the shipping company, did not respond to a request for comment.

"Zim Lines is the largest Israeli shipping company, and it's a huge flow of capital for the state of {Israel}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/israel">,” said Lara Kiswani, executive director of the Arab Resource and Organising Center, one of 70 groups to take part in planning the blockade.

Kiswani said the action was meant to generate momentum for a broader campaign calling for boycott, divestment and sactions aginst the Israeli government as a response to violence in {Gaza.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/gaza"> “With the recent attacks on Palestine … there’s been a lot of discussion locally, particularly with Aroc, on how to escalate our tactics,” she said.

A similar blockade against a Zim vessel took place in 2010, when pro-Palestinian activists formed picket lines in respone to Isreal's attack on a flotilla ferrying humanitarian outreach workers to Gaza. “After the flotilla was attacked by the state of Israel, we successfully were able to block the Zim Lines ship here, with the ILWU,” Kiswani said. “So for years we were working with ILWU, with rank and file, and with the leadership, to try and raise awareness about the plight of Palestinians.” In 1984, she added, “ILWU took a position against apartheid, and the workers refused to unload that ship”.

As the march reached the port entrance, where activists had origianlly planned to stage a picket, they eencountered a line of police officers standing in formation. Protesters erupted into chants of, “hands up, don’t shoot!” – echoing chants sounded in response to police violence directed against street protesters in Ferguson, Missouri, in the wake of the fatal police shotting of 18-year-old Michael Brown.

Several others made statements linking recent acts of police brutality wtih the conflict in Gaza. “On Twitter, we’ve seen people in Gaza tweet to protesters in Ferguson how to cope with teargas,” said Mohamed Shehk, who helped organise the blockade with the Oakland=based nonprofit Critical Resistance. “They’re saying things like, ‘as Palestinians, we know what it’s like to be targeted and killed for being of the wrong ethnicity’.”
TheShitBetween: Blockade delayed as word spreads that ship is off the coast of California, closer to Santa Cruz, and won’t be docking that day

Title: Ten things we learned this week
Author: Frances Perraudin; Aisha Gani; Jade Azim
ArticleText:
The media are not great at reporting suicide
Although Robin Williams’ death has had the positive effect of drawing media attention to the neglected subject of depression – as Roy Greenslade pointed out, {the Telegraph offered information about services for depressed and suicidal people}<hyperlink="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/11030831/Robin-Williams-dies-how-to-access-depression-and-suicide-services.html"> and the Independent gave {a platform to the Samaritans’ chief executive, Catherine Johnson}<hyperlink="http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/robin-williams-dead-quotes-on-depression-and-struggling-with-mental-illness-9665680.html"> – the actor’s suicide wasn’t treated responsibly by everybody.

The Sun ran with a front page story headlined “Robin’s last hours”, containing apparent details of the comedian’s death; the Daily Mirror and the Metro published similar stories. The newspapers were {accused}<hyperlink="http://www.mind.org.uk/news-campaigns/news/mind-comments-on-reporting-of-the-death-of-robin-williams/#.U-3uXS-1ne5"> of contravening guidelines published {by the Samaritans}<hyperlink="http://www.samaritans.org/media-centre/media-guidelines-reporting-suicide"> and the mental health charity {Mind.}<hyperlink="http://www.mind.org.uk/news-campaigns/news/mind-comments-on-reporting-of-the-death-of-robin-williams/#.VxeyEvkrKUm"> Such guidelines suggest that the media shouldn’t report explicit details of suicides as it can lead to copycat behaviour.

“To see what could happen here if the media don’t start reporting Robin Williams’ death more responsibly, you only have to look at what happened in Taiwan after the suicide of a high-profile celebrity, where there was a great deal of media coverage of the method used,” {said writer and broadcaster Claudia Hammond,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/13/robin-williams-media-report-suicide"> presenter of BBC Radio 4’s All in the Mind. “For four weeks {suicide rates}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/society/suicide-rates"> rose.”

A-level students are getting more serious
Usually considered one of the more unpopular school subjects, {maths seems to have had a good year, with more people taking it for A-levels than English for the first time, making it, in fact, the most popular subject.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2014/aug/14/a-level-maths-overtakes-english-students-harder-subjects"> The number of students taking the maths qualification in 2014 rose by 0.9%, while those taking further maths was up 1.5%. Entries for English fell 4.6% but chemistry got a boost, replacing history as the fifth most popular subject.

Many attributed the changing figures to a renewed focus on employability and the move by many Russell Group universities to favour “harder” subjects. Supporting this view was the news that the number of those taking general studies, a subject derided by many as an easy option, dropped by 24%, with PE also seeing a large decline.

The Iraq crisis is now as bad as in Syria
The humanitarian crisis in Iraq is on a par with that in Syria, South Sudan and Central African Republic, the {UN said this week.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/aug/14/iraq-humanitarian-crisis-highest-level-un-aid">

The Kurdish military, with the assistance of US air strikes, has managed to secure a land corridor to allow tens of thousands of people from the Yazidi religious sect to escape from Islamic State militants. Since 6 August, an estimated 80,000 Yazidis and other religious minorities have fled to Syria.

Cliff Richard's house has been raided
{Police have raided a home}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/aug/14/cliff-richard-house-search-claims-sexual-abuse-billy-graham-rally-1985> belonging to the singer Cliff Richard as part of an investigation into an alleged sexual assault on a boy in the 1980s.

Detectives are investigating a claim that a boy, who was under 16 at the time, was abused at a rally held by the evangelical US preacher Billy Graham in 1985 at Sheffield United football club’s Bramall Lane stadium.

In a statement, Richard described the allegations as completely false. “For many months I have been aware of allegations against me of historic impropriety which have been circulating online,” he said. “Up until now I have chosen not to dignify the false allegations with a response, as it would just give them more oxygen.”

He said that it would be inappropriate to say anything further as police investigations are ongoing.

A woman wins the Fields Medal maths prize for the first time
Yes, women can do maths, and the Iranian mathematician {Maryam Mirzakhani made history this week when she became the first female winner of the Fields Medal,}<hyperlink="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/aug/13/fields-medal-mathematics-prize-woman-maryam-mirzakhani"> often described as the Nobel prize for mathematics. The 37-year-old Stanford University professor, born and raised in Tehran, describes the language of maths as full of “beauty and elegance” and {says she became fascinated with the subject}<hyperlink="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/aug/13/interview-maryam-mirzakhani-fields-medal-winner-mathematician"> when her brother used to come home and talk about what he had learned at school. 

By the time she was a teenager, Mirzakhani was taking part in international maths olympiads, winning gold medals in 1994 and 1995. She completed a PhD at Harvard in 2004 and works on problems related to geometric structures on surfaces and their deformations. 

What is inspiring is that she didn’t always want to do maths; she dreamed of becoming a writer when she was a child. There have been 55 Fields medallists since the prize was first awarded in 1936, including this year’s winners.

• {Interview: ‘The more I spent time on maths, the more excited I got’}<hyperlink="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/aug/13/interview-maryam-mirzakhani-fields-medal-winner-mathematician">
• {The maths of Mirzakhani, Avila, Bhargava and Hairer explained}<hyperlink="https://www.theguardian.com/science/alexs-adventures-in-numberland/2014/aug/13/fields-medals-2014-maths-avila-bhargava-hairer-mirzakhani">
• {Prizes for maths work that few of us can grasp}<hyperlink="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/aug/13/field-medals-2014-prizes-maths-work-few-grasp">
• {Why did it take so long for a woman to win the Fields Medal?}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/13/woman-wins-fields-medal-odds-maryam-mirzakhani">

Egypt massacre last year was premeditated, rights group says
In what became one of the bloodiest days in modern history, Egyptian security forces intentionally killed at least 817 protesters in Rabaa a year ago, according to a Human Rights Watch report. The killings were reminiscent of the 1989 Tiananmen Square killings in China: they were systematic, widespread and “probably amount to crimes against humanity”. 

It recommended that several senior individuals, including President {Abdel Fatah al-Sisi,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/22/abdel-fatah-al-sisi-egypt-president"> are investigated and held to account for their role in planning the massacre, which occurred in August 2013 during the dispersal of {a six-week-old encampment in Cairo’s}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/12/egypt-cairo-mohamed-morsi-camps"> Al-Adawiya Square, set up by demonstrators protesting the overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi. The report states that the camp’s estimated 85,000 protesters were not given enough time to leave before troops started firing and were prevented for from leaving via safe exits.

Speaking to the Guardian, 61-year-old former oil worker Hussein Abdel Aal said he had witnessed his son Ramzy being shot dead by a sniper. He said Ramzy was standing far from the edge of the camp and “did not have any kind of weapons. From the stick to the gun, he had nothing.”

• Egypt massacre was premeditated, says Human Rights Watch
• {Read Human Rights Watch report}<hyperlink="https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/08/12/egypt-raba-killings-likely-crimes-against-humanity">

Humans talks of 'real chance' for Gaza agreement with Israel
After a five-week-long war in Gaza, {mediators in Cairo brokered a five-day extension to the current ceasefire shortly before a midnight deadline on Wednesday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/gaza-conflict-israel-hamas-extend-ceasefire">

Efforts to extend the truce went to the wire and Hamas, the Islamist organisation in power in Gaza, said it believed there was a “real opportunity” to reach an agreement with {Israel}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/israel"> to end the conflict in Gaza. 

{Hamas}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/hamas"> negotiator Khalil al-Hayya told reporters: “There is still a real chance to clinch an agreement, but Israel must stop playing with words.” He added: “We are not interested in more destruction for our people. We are not interested in more bloodshed.”

Egyptian mediators appeared to be striving for a two-part agreement:

1) Easing Israeli restrictions on imports and exports, increasing the number of permits issued to Gazans to enter or travel through Israel, reducing the size of the no-go “buffer zone” inside Gaza’s perimeter, and expanding the permitted fishing zone.

2) To follow some weeks later, a focus on Hamas’s demands for a sea and airport, and the possible release of some Palestinian prisoners in exchange for the remains of two Israeli soldiers killed in the conflict which Hamas is believed to be holding as a bargaining tool.

Hamas also wants the Rafah crossing between Gaza and Egypt to be opened, possibly policed by Palestinian Authority security forces.

Gaza has been under an Israeli blockade since 2006 that has sent unemployment and poverty soaring.

Russian military vehicles enter Ukraine as aid convoy stops short
While a {convoy of Russian trucks carrying humanitarian aid arrived close to the border of Ukraine}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/14/russian-convoy-stops-close-to-ukraine-border"> on Thursday, the Guardian saw a column of 23 armoured personnel carriers, supported by fuel trucks and other logistics vehicles with official Russian military plates, travelling towards the border near the Russian town of Donetsk, Ukraine.

The {Guardian’s Shaun Walker reports}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/14/russian-military-vehicles-enter-ukraine-aid-convoy-stops-short-border">:

"After pausing by the side of the road until nightfall, the convoy crossed into Ukrainian territory, using a rough dirt track and clearly crossing through a gap in a barbed wire fence that demarcates the border. Armed men were visible in the gloom by the border fence as the column moved into Ukraine. Kiev has lost control of its side of the border in this area.
The trucks are unlikely to represent a full-scale official Russian invasion, and it was unclear how far they planned to travel inside Ukrainian territory and how long they would stay. But it was incontrovertible evidence of what Ukraine has long claimed – that Russian troops are active inside its borders.”

Walker also tweeted a photo:

[tweetbegin 499961048448126978 tweetend]

According to Moscow, the convoy is a goodwill gesture, packed with aid for the residents of eastern Ukraine. However in Kiev’s view, the convoy is at best a cynical ploy and at worst, a kind of Trojan centipede. The armoured vehicles seen by the Guardian are further evidence of Russia’s incursions, which the Kremlin has repeatedly denied

Sharks take a bite out of Google
In a case of nature v technology, sharks have been biting the world’s undersea data cables. As a result Google, the internet giant, has gone to great lengths to reinforce underwater fibre-optic cables, which carry internet traffic across the globe at 1 gigabit per second.

This {YouTube video}<hyperlink="https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=1ex7uTQf4bQ"> shows a shark in the Pacific Ocean biting down on a cable, which is protected by several layers against damage that would otherwise break glass fibres. It is thought that sharks may be attracted to the magnetic field, something suggested by the lack of attacks on older, slower, copper cables.

Calm descends over Ferguson after four nights of violence
Thursday evening saw {reduced clashes in the small suburb of Ferguson, Missouri,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/15/ferguson-disarming-tactics-of-highway-patrol-pay-dividends-as-calm-descends"> over the death of unarmed teenager Michael Brown and subsequent claims of police brutality toward African-Americans.

The initial operation – this included highly militarised police officers reportedly throwing tear gas and firing rubber bullets at the largely unarmed protesters, the shutting down of roads leading into the city and the implementation of a no-fly Zone – was replaced on the demand of the state governor, Jay Nixon, who had been urged by Barack Obama to restore peace. Veteran civil rights activist John Lewis had also suggested that troops under federal control should replace local police, although Obama did not go so far as to condemn the latter. The change of tactics saw a reduction in the police presence and the appointment of a new police chief on the ground, Ron Johnson.

Rena Perry, 33, who had been among the crowds, said: “It’s just so different. The other nights the police were over there and we was over here. It was a war. This new guy has changed the atmosphere.” 

People gathered at a large intersection in a carnival-like demonstration. However, Johnson refused to rule out the use of military-style equipment that had initially attracted such controversy. Obama has called for a report on the events in Ferguson from the attorney general, Eric Holder.

• {Michael Brown shooting: help the world hear your police racial profiling story}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/13/michael-brown-shooting-police-racial-profiling-ferguson">
TheShitBetween: From A-level students getting more serious to sharks attacking Google – a roundup of the week’s news

Title: Politicians: they're not like us. But some folks sure like to eat photo-op corn dogs
Author: Ana Marie Cox
ArticleText:
It’s folksy season again in politics. Obama’s on the Vineyard, showing off his mom jeans on a regular basis. Members of Congress – and 2016 hopefuls – are out on recess, racing from fair to fair to eat various {foods}<hyperlink="http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/opinion/columnists/kathie-obradovich/2014/08/06/iowa-state-fair-candidates-etiquette/13701463/"> on {sticks.}<hyperlink="https://www.google.com/search?q=corn+dog+michele+bachmann&espv=2&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=qBLtU4nDEo21yASWz4CwBA&ved=0CBwQsAQ&biw=842&bih=402"> Casual Friday politics is even showing up in our rhetoric: Obama feels bad about that we {“tortured some folks”}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/01/obama-cia-torture-some-folks-brennan-spying">; Hillary wants to {“hug it out”.}<hyperlink="http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/215043-white-house-says-media-wont-see-obama-clinton-hug-it-out">

Adopting a summer-y populist pose reached an absurd level of vulgarity here in Minnesota, where independently wealthy US Senate candidate Mike McFadden released an ad that shows him {getting hit in the nuts}<hyperlink="https://www.minnpost.com/party-politics/2014/07/senate-candidate-mike-mcfaddens-groin-gate-ad-named-best-summer"> while coaching little league football. Nothing says “man of the people” like a groin injury.

But “understanding the problems of people like you” isn’t necessarily about state fairs and coffee shops. Rand Paul, for instance, {has already gotten dinged}<hyperlink="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2724088/Rand-Paul-caught-partying-Hamptons-skipping-conservative-event-family-commitment.html"> for {skipping}<hyperlink="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/rand-paul-skips-iowa-event-spotted-in-the-hamptons/"> this weekend’s Family Leadership Summit in Ames, Iowa ... in favor of a library fundraiser in the Hamptons. But I kind of respect anyone who would turn down the chance to pander to a bunch of ideologically rigid creationists in favor of promoting, you know, reading. I couldn’t tell you the last time Mike Bloomberg or George Soros ate corn dogs, but few progressives will turn their money down.

And state fairs do not automatically lead to the image of a humble public servant, just trying to do right by real Americans. Rick Perry went to the Iowa state fair, ate some bacon, then gave a speech in which he concluded, {“I’m awesome!”}<hyperlink="http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/elections/2014/08/12/rick-perry-does-the-iowa-state-fair/13965353/"> (Just don’t ask him to give three reasons why.)

But seriously: it’s all cowboy boots and coffee shops until the budget cuts come. The most horrid offenses against the poor and middle class have often come at the hands of the class-identity manipulators most skilled in affecting the appearance of jes’ plain folks. Bush cleared brush as he {proposed}<hyperlink="http://www.thenation.com/article/bushs-war-poor"> a $1bn cut in child welfare. Perry’s twang is no comfort to the {1.2m Texans left out of Obamacare’s Medicaid expansion.}<hyperlink="http://www.ksat.com/news/lawmakers-mull-alternatives-to-medicaid-expansion">

Even politicians who can legitimately claim middle-class experience tend to legislate aspirationally. They can “feel our pain”, but politicians really want to be above the crowd. And being in Congress is a good way get rich with minimal effort. Members of Congress routinely find their {net worth increasing}<hyperlink="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/01/congress-net-wealth-income-gap_n_1069377.html"> while Americans see steep decreases; their stock portfolios {perform up to 10% better}<hyperlink="http://finance.townhall.com/columnists/johnransom/2011/05/26/how_to_go_to_congress_and_become_a_millionaire"> than the average investor.

Even the threat of being voted out of office – or impeached, let’s say – isn’t anything like a real person losing a job. However Obama leaves office, he then becomes a member of lots of corporate boards and gets paid millions on the speakers circuit. That’ll show him! The Clintons may have been {“dead broke”}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jun/24/hillary-clinton-income-inequality-2016-election"> when they left the White House, but their path to financial security was a smooth downhill run: How will we get out of debt? Better keep being the Clintons! Failed down-home Republican candidates {get their own TV shows}<hyperlink="https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=huckabee%20net%20worth"> – or {their own TV shows and TV channels.}<hyperlink="http://www.politico.com/story/2014/07/sarah-palin-online-tv-channel-109429">

The lives of national political figures aren’t just like ours – and to some degree that’s understandable and necessary, if only for their personal security. But what if they – at some point – took real jobs? And “running a business” doesn’t count. As stunty as Undercover Boss is, there is a real point to it, and something like that might be the best we can hope for.

Or if it’s just too much to ask for policies back in Washington to reflect the lived experience of most Americans on display during our national politicians’ five-week vacation, how about being on the ground when matters on a more urgent, personal level? How about going beyond beyond butter cows, steak fries or even parachute-in appearances such as Obama’s front porch tour? Will we ever see a president – or 2016 contender – march on today’s picket lines, take the food-stamp challenge, or join in the peaceful Ferguson demonstrations rather than opine about them?

Proving one’s middle-class bona fides – or using someone’s wealth as proof of distance from it – is so ingrained in the American political discourse it’s hard to even differentiate it as a specific tactic. But imagine if the standard was not whether or not one appears to be “of the people” and rather showed a willingness to defer to them.
TheShitBetween: Rick Perry’s ‘awesome’ adventure. Rand Paul’s Hamptons weekend. Which classist lie will you believe this summer?

Title: Barack Obama breaks vacation for meetings in Washington
Author: Associated Press
ArticleText:
President {Barack Obama}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/barack-obama"> planned a break in the middle of his vacation to return to Washington on Sunday night, for unspecified meetings with Vice-President Joe Biden and other advisers.

The White House has been cagey about why the president needs to be back in Washington for those discussions. Part of the decision appears aimed at countering criticism that Obama is spending two weeks on a resort island in the midst of so many foreign and domestic crises.

Yet those crises turned the first week of Obama’s vacation into a working holiday. He made {on-camera statements}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2014/aug/15/iraq-us-broke-isis-siege-mount-sinjar-obama-video"> on US military action in Iraq and the clashes between police and protesters in Ferguson, Missouri. He called foreign leaders to discuss the tensions between Ukraine and Russia, as well as between Israel and Hamas.

“I think it’s fair to say there are, of course, ongoing complicated situations in the world, and that’s why you’ve seen the president stay engaged,” the White House spokesman, Eric Schultz, said.

Obama is scheduled to return to Martha’s Vineyard on Tuesday and stay through next weekend.

Even though work has occupied much of Obama’s first week on vacation, he still found plenty of time to play golf, go to the beach with his family and go out to dinner on the island. He also attended a birthday party for Democratic adviser Vernon Jordan’s wife, where he spent time with former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

That get-together between the former rivals-turned-partners added another complicated dynamic to Obama’s vacation. Just as Obama was arriving on Martha’s Vineyard, an interview with the former secretary of state was published in which she levied some of her sharpest {criticism of Obama’s foreign policy.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/hillary-clinton-barack-obama-policy-syria-israel">

Clinton later promised she and Obama would “hug it out” when they saw each other at Jordan’s party. No reporters were allowed in, so it is not clear whether there was any hugging, but the White House said the president danced to nearly every song.
TheShitBetween:
• President will meet vice-president and other advisers
• Stay in Martha’s Vineyard has been disrupted by crises

Title: David Cameron asked to clarify UK role in Iraq amid conflicting signals
Author: Nicholas Watt; Rajeev Syal
ArticleText:
{David Cameron}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/davidcameron"> was accused on Monday of a lack of clarity over Iraq amid apparently conflicting signals from ministers on Britain's growing involvement in the crisis in the country.

As the Pope endorsed the use of force to stop jihadists from the {Islamic State}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/isis"> (Isis) attacking religious minorities in northern Iraq, the shadow foreign secretary, Douglas Alexander, accused ministers of making confusing statements.

Alexander, who was speaking after the defence secretary, {Michael Fallon,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/michael-fallon"> said Britain was no longer involved in "simply a humanitarian mission" in Iraq, told the BBC: "I do think there is a case for clarity being brought to the respective statements of the foreign secretary and defence secretary."

The prime minister sought to clarify Fallon's remarks by making clear there would be limits to Britain's involvement. Cameron told BBC1's Breakfast programme on Monday: "Britain is not going to get involved in another war in {Iraq.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/iraq"> We are not going to be putting boots on the ground. We are not going to be sending in the British army."

The prime minister, who rejected calls for parliament to be recalled to discuss the Iraq crisis, insisted that there is a clear strategy to tackle the Isis extremists. He added: "We should use all the assets we have – our diplomacy, our political relationships, our aid, the military prowess and expertise we have to help others – as part of a strategy to put pressure on Islamic State and make sure this terrorist organisation is properly addressed and it cannot cause mayhem on our own streets."

But Alexander said: "It would be important to understand the nature of the mission that British forces are now engaged in. Does that remain primarily focused on the humanitarian efforts? Because the humanitarian need continues to be huge."

{Labour}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/labour"> believes ministers have been stumbling from one decision to another on Iraq. Downing Street announced last week that Tornado jets would be despatched to the region to monitor the needs of the Yazidi refugees besieged on Mount Sinjar. The Tornados are now conducting surveillance missions of Isis forces deep into Iraq.

Downing Street initially said it would only transport arms to Kurdish forces on behalf of other EU countries. But it then said it was prepared to supply British arms if requested. No 10 said that the British mission in Iraq was solely humanitarian. Fallon extended this over the weekend when he said that British warplanes are flying deep into Iraq to gather intelligence in a mission that could last "months".

The prime minister, who left the foreign secretary, Philip Hammond, to chair a Cobra meeting as he delivered a speech on the family, resumed his holiday on Monday when he travelled to Cornwall after flying on government business to Exeter for a photo opportunity related to his speech.

A spokesman for Cameron said last night he had discussed the crisis with regional leaders in the Middle East including the Saudi and Jordanian kings and the emir of Qatar.

Cameron's decision to resume his holiday in Britain, after a week in Portugal, followed the decision of {Barack Obama to return to Washington from his holiday on Martha's Vineyard}<hyperlink="http://www.usatoday.com/story/theoval/2014/08/17/obama-white-house-return-marthas-vineyard/14193419/"> to discuss the Iraq crisis and the disturbances in Ferguson, Missouri. The president is due to return to Martha's Vineyard on Tuesday.

Pope Francis said that he was considering with advisers whether to travel to Iraq to show solidarity with persecuted Christians. However, a decision has not yet been made, according to the Associated Press.

Asked by journalists on his flight back to the Vatican from South Korea whether he approved of the US air strikes against Isis, the Pope said: "In these cases, where there is an unjust aggression, I can only say that it is licit to stop the unjust aggressor.

"I underscore the verb 'stop'. I'm not saying 'bomb' or 'make war', just 'stop'. And the means that can be used to stop them must be evaluated."
TheShitBetween: PM says army will not be sent into conflict as Labour accuses ministers of making confusing statements

Title: The holiday trap: the tricky business of a leader's leisure time
Author: Michael White
ArticleText:
Barack Obama once advised {David Cameron}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/davidcameron"> that one habit he should learn to get right as a new prime minister would be allowing himself enough free time to think hard about problems. The president was right, of course. Summer holiday breaks provide an excellent opportunity to get off the treadmill and do just that while playing beach cricket with the kids.

But voters and their crowd-pleasing media don't like it. In today's puritan times, people who pay their way by the sweat of their brow or chained to a computer mouse are suspicious of merely cerebral activity as well as the sight of an elected public official enjoying him or herself in the sunshine. That applies even when August is a quiet month – as it so often hasn't been since the guns opened fire 100 summers ago. Whether chilled like Cameron or Blair, or tense like Thatcher or Gordon Brown, politicians just can't win.

So when a shirt-sleeved William Gladstone – "the People's William" – allowed himself to be photographed relaxing (he liked chopping down trees on his estate in north Wales), he signed a Faustian pact the paparazzi exploit to this day: the political holiday shot, granted in the hope of winning a few admiring votes and being left alone. US President Theodore Roosevelt (1901-9) thrived on hunting-and-fishing action shots. Vladimir Putin still does.

Gladstone the intellectual also liked staying at smart seaside resorts (no photo opportunities there) in France where Ed Miliband is this summer. Just back from Portugal – he went to the Canaries at Easter – Cameron is now off to a family break in north Cornwall again, scene of the Hooray Henry holidays of his teens around the Camel estuary. Nick Clegg is with the in-laws as usual in Spain. Theresa May has been in the Alps (surely a coincidence that Thatcher did the same?) while Yvette Cooper and Ed Balls bravely took their three kids on a week-long train journey to Greece via Venice and Vienna.

At least European leaders have their passports, though Berlusconi's, Sarkozy's and Chirac's weakness for exotic extravagance was no more popular than Tony Blair's search for palazzos in Tuscany and Freebie. Solid, sensible Angela Merkel prefers to walk in the mountains with her invisible hubbie. By contrast, US presidents daren't vacation abroad ("what's wrong with America?") and are warned off elite locations for the rich. "Can I fish if I don't catch anything?" Bill Clinton once moaned, though hedonistic Clinton could enjoy himself in a padded cell.

Obama has an alibi. Like George W Bush working on his mini-ranch in Texas, he can and does holiday in distant Hawaii on the unarguable grounds that it is both home and US soil. It doesn't prevent media storms ("why is Michelle staying on?") like the one which forced him to take a break from golf in rich Martha's Vinyard as Ferguson rioted over the police shooting of Michael Brown. As for New York's leftwing mayor, Bill de Blasio, he went home too, but to Italy where he savoured delicious three-hour lunches: very unAmerican. August is New York's media silly season too.

The real complaint against political summer holidays are that they are too long. Parliament now comes back for two pre-conference weeks in September. It has not stopped some MPs and newspapers (even the FT) demanding an early recall to debate options for the crisis in Iraq and or Ukraine rather than leaving it to novice ministers like Phil Hammond and Michael Fallon. It is true "quiet August" is not a policy that would obtain low-cost insurance. The 2007-2009 banking crisis first boiled up in August, as did Suez (1956), Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait (1990) and Russian troops entry into Prague (1968). The Berlin Wall went up in August (1961) while Hitler and Stalin did their deal in August 1939, which guaranteed the second world war. The Kaiser's troops marched west in August 1914.

As Cameron will vividly remember it was also in August (2013) that MPs recalled from the beach voted against military intervention in Syria; little wonder he is not keen to summon them now. But that decision reflects only the democratic legitimation side of the policymaker's ledger. In a wired age of (mostly) secure high-speed internet communications unimaginable even in Thatcher's day, the flow of information and options for near-instant communications with Whitehall or the White House make executive decision-making a practical reality.

It was not so when sterling's gold standard crisis of 1931 forced Tory leader, Stanley Baldwin, to break his usual month in the tranquil French Alps to return to London (twice), by train, not RAF helicopter. So when Cameron protests, as he did again this month, that "wherever I am in the world I am always within a few feet of a Blackberry and able to manage things should they need to be managed," he spoke the truth.

Fellow Etonian and famously unflappable Harold Macmillan would have approved from his languid August grouse moor. But symbolism sometimes still dictates otherwise, requiring an aspiring statesman to show hands-on leadership by making a pointless journey for the TV cameras. Macmillan the showman would have understood that. So would Gladstone the axeman.
TheShitBetween: Whether chilling like David Cameron or tense like Gordon Brown, politicians can't win in August – a usually explosive month

Title: Ferguson protests: Michael Brown family calls for calm amid criticism of video release – as it happened
Author: Tom McCarthy
ArticleText:
Key events

15 Aug 2014: {Brown family: 'We do not want...any violence'}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson?page=with:block-

53ee7000e4b038fb92169b38#block-53ee7000e4b038fb92169b38">

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson?page=with:block-

53ee5c8de4b0f5010eedd932#block-53ee5c8de4b0f5010eedd932">

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson?page=with:block-

53ee5b52e4b0f5010eedd931#block-53ee5b52e4b0f5010eedd931">

15 Aug 2014: {Brown family: we are 'beyond outraged' at 'devious' police}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson?page=with:block-

53ee467ee4b0d0d62bdb71cf#block-53ee467ee4b0d0d62bdb71cf">

15 Aug 2014: {Dorian Johnson lawyer: client described stealing cigars}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson?page=with:block-

53ee303ae4b0f5010eedd8fb#block-53ee303ae4b0f5010eedd8fb">

Live feed

15 Aug 2014 18:10: We’re going to wrap up our live blog coverage for the time being. 

We will post updates this evening on {our home page.}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us">

Follow the Guardian’s Rory Carroll ({@rorycarroll72}

<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/rorycarroll72">) and Jon Swaine ({@jonswaine}

<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/jonswaine">) for ongoing reporting from Ferguson.

Here's a summary of where things stand:

• A day of fast-paced developments in Ferguson, Missouri, ended with attorneys for the 

family of Michael Brown, 18, calling for calm in the streets and praising the work of 

Governor Jay Nixon and President Barack Obama.

• The family had a harsher appraisal of the local police force, who this morning released 

the name of the officer who shot Brown dead on 9 August. He is Darren Wilson, a 6-year 

veteran.

• Simultaneous to the release of Wilson’s name, Ferguson police released an incident 

report naming Brown as a suspect in an alleged store robbery. The report included 

surveillance images of a man, apparently Brown, standing over a store clerk. Later police 

released {video}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee4887e4b0f5010eedd925"> of the 

incident.

• Ferguson police chief Thomas Jackson said Friday afternoon that officer Wilson 

stopped Brown because Brown was “blocking traffic” – and not in connection with the 

alleged robbery.

• The family said the release of the video and incident report was designed to distract 

attention from the police killing of Brown. “It was a character assassination,” a lawyer for 

the family said.

• Many protesters {expressed anger}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee2b15e4b0d0d62bdb71c0"> at the 

police decision to release the report on the alleged robbery without releasing any report 

about the killing of Brown.

• The family {said}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee7000e4b038fb92169b38"> they had 

faith in an ongoing federal investigation into Brown’s killing. “Justice is moving now, in 

the right direction,” Brown’s mother was quoted by a family attorney as saying.

• Ferguson police claimed that apart from a “{use of force report}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee5a97e4b06c461acbb5c1">”, the 

department retains no documents pertaining to the killing of Brown by one of its 

officers. “We have given you everything we have now,” Jackson said.

• Read the {previous summay here.}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee3a93e4b0d0d62bdb71cc">

15 Aug 2014 17:38: The Guardian's Rory Carroll is in Ferguson:

[tweetbegin 500395665738846208 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 17:26: In a memorable moment in the Brown family news conference, Eric 

Davis, a cousin of the victim, {got to his knees}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee71dce4b0d0d62bdb71da"> with his 

hands up to demonstrate the position he said Michael Brown had assumed before being 

shot. The position is the universal code for “I surrender,” Davis said.

In an interview {with MSNBC,}<hyperlink="http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/eyewitness-

michael-brown-fatal-shooting-missouri"> Dorian Johnson, who was with Brown when he 

was killed, described Brown raising his hands but said Brown was in a standing position 

at the time and then “crumbled” to the ground.

Johnson told MSNBC:

"Brown made it past the third car. Then, “blam!” the officer took his second shot, striking 

Brown in the back. At that point, Johnson says Brown stopped, turned with his hands up 

and said “I don’t have a gun, stop shooting!”
By that point, Johnson says the officer and Brown were face-to-face. The officer then 

fired several more shots. Johnson described watching Brown go from standing with his 

hands up to crumbling to the ground and curling into a fetal position."

[tweetbegin 500389623307456514 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 17:12: A live stream of the news conference with Jay Kanzler, an attorney 

for the owners of Ferguson Market and Liquor, which police suspected Michael Brown 

of robbing, {is here.}<hyperlink="http://fox2now.com/on-air/live-streaming-2/">

Kanzler says the county police issued a warrant today for surveillance video from the 

store.

[tweetbegin 500389021910974465 tweetend]

“They are members of the community that want nothing more than [a return] to peace 

and calm,” he says. He says the owners did not know Michael Brown.

He wraps the brief news conference.

15 Aug 2014 17:01: Next up: the owner of the store where the alleged robbery occurred:

[tweetbegin 500385913512677377 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 16:57: Two more lines from the news conference just ended, regarding 

police communication with the family and the autopsy:

[tweetbegin 500384298088665088 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 500385072608862208 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 16:55: Parks concludes the news conference.

“This has been very hard for the mother and father,” he says.

“We hope to see you all at 3 o’clock downtown on Sunday. The family will do their best 

to make it there.”

15 Aug 2014 16:51: Parks says when Brown’s mother saw what the chief had done, she 

said, “why would he do that?”

“And so she thought it was very important that everyone here know.. that she is 

[satisfied] with where the investigation is, and [she wants] everyone remain calm."

“Justice is moving now, in the right direction,” Parks quotes Brown’s mother as saying.

15 Aug 2014 16:49: Parks says the person in the surveillance video “appears to be him” 

– Brown.

15 Aug 2014 16:49: Brown family: 'We do not want...any violence'

Next a family friend, a cousin named Eric Davis, speaks. He gets on his hands and knees, 

arms up, and narrates what happened to Brown:

"...getting down on his hands and knees, his hands in the air, and saying don’t shoot!
That is wrong, and we want the truth to come out.
We’re asking the community to please support us.. but do not get distracted, we do not 

want to see any violence in the street."

At 3pm Sunday the family will hold a rally downtown, Parks says.

[tweetbegin 500384183902937088 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 16:47: A second lawyer, Anthony Gray, speaks. He says Brown had his 

hands in the air and was still shot.

He says Brown’s parents have acknowledged that their son had had discipline problems.

He says no matter what further pictures or anything else that may come out, the focus 

should be on the police killing of Brown.

“The family feels that that was strategic, they feel that it was aimed at denigrating their 

son, it was a character assassination,” Gray says.

"He’s now inciting the community all over again. If you get this kind of negative reaction 

to this... it won’t be on anybody’s part on this side. .. Now we’re focused on the side 

show.
Do not take the bait from anybody who is trying to character assassinate Mike. Don’t 

take that..."

15 Aug 2014 16:43: Brown lawayer: 'we totally trust' federal investigation

Daryl Parks, a lawyer for the Brown family, is speaking at a news conference.

“The video has nothing to do with how he was killed on that day,” Parks says, referring 

to the convenience store surveillance video.

The Feds are conducting a full investigation. They have talked to the mother, he says.

“On behalf of the family, we totally trust the investigation that they are doing,” he says.

“Lastly, we want to thank everyone. THe family particularly wants to thank Governor 

Nixon....We also want to thank President Obama.

"This family has belonged to this community for a long time.
They want nothing less than law and order tonight. ... As we remember Mike Brown.
We believe the most important thing, is what happened that particular day, in the middle 

of the street, is that officer killed Mike Brown. Let’s not lose sight of that."

15 Aug 2014 16:34: You can watch the Brown family news conference, expected to 

begin soon, on NBC News online:

[tweetbegin 500379436932694016 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 16:28: More media time for {Ferguson}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> police chief Thomas 

Jackson. (Where’s the TV camera?)

[tweetbegin 500378130771501056 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 16:25: Local reporters find Jackson’s explanation for releasing the 

surveillance video – a need to be responsive to freedom of information requests – not 

plausible:

[tweetbegin 500365507501891584 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 16:22: The Brown family will host a news conference scheduled to begin 

shortly.

[tweetbegin 500372482793414657 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 16:05: Ferguson police chief Thomas Jackson’s statement Friday afternoon 

that Officer Darren Wilson did not stop Michael Brown in connection with an alleged 

robbery minutes early seems clearly to contradict an account of the stop earlier Friday 

by... {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> police 

chief Thomas Jackson.

On Friday morning, chief Jackson said Wilson “left a sick call” after “dispatch gave a 

description of a robbery suspect over the radio.” The seemingly clear implication was 

that Wilson left the sick call expressly to seek the suspect in the alleged robbery.

This recording is from CNN’s broadcast of chief Jackson’s news conference Friday 

morning:

{Ferguson chief: 'description of a robbery suspect over the radio'}

<hyperlink="https://soundcloud.com/tommccarthy-3/ferguson-chief-description-of-a-

robbery-suspect-over-the-radio">

Chief Jackson said:

"At 11.52, dispatch gave a description of a robbery suspect over the radio. A different 

officer arrived at the store where the strongarm robbery occurred.
A further description, more detailed, was given over the radio, and uh, stated the officer 

was walking toward – er the uh, suspect was walking toward QuikTrip. Our officer left the 

sick call, he encoutered, uh uh, encountered the, uh, I’m sorry.
At 12.01 our officer encountered Michael Brown on Canfield Drive. At 12.04 a second 

officer arrived on the scene, immediately following the shooting and at 12.05 a 

supervisor was detached, dispatched to the scene, and subsequent officers arrived."

15 Aug 2014 15:39: 'Blocking traffic'

[tweetbegin 500363899037052928 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 15:28: This question persists, despite chief Jackson’s {explanation}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee5a97e4b06c461acbb5c1"> that he 

released the surveillance video due to pressure from numerous freedom of information 

requests:

[tweetbegin 500359905316859904 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 500364014472290305 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 500359114350800896 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 15:17: Ferguson chief: Wilson 'a gentle, quiet man'

Jackson is asked about Darren Wilson.

“He was a gentle, quiet man, he was a distinguished officer,” Jackson says. “He was a 

gentleman, a quiet officer. He is, has been” a good officer. 

“It’s devastating. He never intended for this to happen.”

15 Aug 2014 15:16: Jackson is asked: If the alleged robbery had nothing to do with 

Brown being stopped, then why would you release the video of the robbery?

“Because you asked for it,” Jackson says.

Jackson again refers to county police for any further information about the killing of 

Brown.

15 Aug 2014 15:15: Jackson says the officer who stopped Brown did not stop him in 

connection with the alleged robbery. Brown was stopped, Jackson says, “Because he was 

walking down the middle of the street blocking traffic. That was it.”

Jackson says officer Darren Wilson had served two years with Jennings police and four 

years with {Ferguson.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson">

15 Aug 2014 15:12: Ferguson chief: 'We have given you everything we have'

Jackson is asked about the Brown family statement of outrage at the piecemeal release 

of information by the police.

“My response to that is my heart goes out to the family...

We have given you everything we have now, everything we can give you."

15 Aug 2014 15:11: Jackson says he can’t release further information – the description 

of the Brown killing, he means – because it pertains to an ongoing investigation.

“There is a use of force report that we have,” Jackson says. He says all reports on this will 

be written by the county police.

As for the incident report in the Brown killing, “I don’t have it in my possession,” Jackson 

says. “Everything belongs to the county.

“What I did was release the video tape to you because I had to. I didn’t sit on it. Too 

many people put in FOI requests.”

15 Aug 2014 15:07: The {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-

news/ferguson"> police chief Thomas Jackson is holding a news conference. “We’ve 

pretty much given you every bit of information we have now,” he says.

He said the surveillance video was released because “We didn’t have good cause to not 

release it under FOI.”

“We decided at the same time it wouldn’t be prudent to release that information that 

could be a little bit, uh, I don’t know [...]
We’ve pretty much given you every bit of information we have now. I don’t think there’s 

anything else to give out."

15 Aug 2014 15:05: Video: “They killed him for no reason”

A video has been uploaded to YouTube recorded by a bystander in the immediate 

aftermath of the Michael Brown killing. The ten-minute video shows Brown’s body lying 

in the street in a pool of blood. The area is cordoned off with police tape.

Additional police arrive at the scene as residents gather outside the tape. Residents yell 

at police, accusing them of murder and demanding an ambulance. “Ain’t no ambulance,” 

the video narrator says. “He’s gone.”

Warning: The images and language in the video are graphic. You can watch it {here.}

<hyperlink="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VdL9dqkyjhM">

15 Aug 2014 14:52: The Senate intends to review the program under which the 

Pentagon transfers military gear and weapons to local police departments, Guardian US 

national security editor Spencer Ackerman ({@attackerman}

<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/attackerman">) reports:

"The head of the Senate Armed Services Committee says he intends to review the 

Defense Department’s increasingly controversial transfers of military surplus equipment, 

weapons and vehicles to local police, a flashpoint issue in the police suppression of 

protest in {Ferguson,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> 

Missouri and elsewhere.
Known as the 1033 program, the purpose of the transfers was to ensure police were able 

to withstand comparatively well-armed drug networks. Along with grant money provided 

by the Department of Homeland Security in the wake of 9/11, it has enabled police 

departments around the country to increasingly kit themselves like military units, even 

for routine policework.
“Congress established this program out of real concern that local law enforcement 

agencies were literally outgunned by drug criminals. We intended this equipment to 

keep police officers and their communities safe from heavily armed drug gangs and 

terrorist incidents. Before the defense authorization bill comes to the Senate floor, we 

will review this program to determine if equipment provided by the Defense Department 

is being used as intended,” Sen. Carl Levin, a retiring Michigan Democrat, said on Friday."

The Ferguson, Missouri police department {participates}

<hyperlink="http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_POLICE_SHOOTING_MISSOURI

_MILITARY_GEAR?SITE=VALYD&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT"> in the 1033 

program. Spencer continues:

"On Thursday, Rear Adm. John Kirby, the Pentagon press secretary, defended the surplus 

transfers.
“This is a useful program that allows for the re-use of military equipment that otherwise 

would be disposed of that can be used again by law enforcement agencies to serve their 

citizens. The program serves a purpose,” Kirby said.
“That said, it is up to law enforcement agencies to speak to how and what they gain 

through this system, and I’m not going to inject the Pentagon into this discussion. How 

this equipment is used to serve local citizens is up for local law enforcement agencies to 

speak to.”"

15 Aug 2014 14:45: A “power to the people” voter registration drive in {Ferguson}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> – via the president of the 

St Louis board of aldermen:

{— Lewis E. Reed (@PresReed)}

<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/PresReed/statuses/500351980892856320">

Also in {#Ferguson}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Ferguson?src=hash"> now 

{pic.twitter.com/tkXLfHgDXR}<hyperlink="http://t.co/tkXLfHgDXR">

15 Aug 2014 14:31: The Guardian’s Rory Carroll is in {Ferguson.}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> He reports that police 

are protecting the convenience store where the alleged robbery took place:

[tweetbegin 500348529915617281 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 14:23

15 Aug 2014 14:13: There are {reports}

<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/RobertDEdwards/status/500336112171495425"> that 

Ferguson police chief Thomas Jackson will hold another news conference at about 3pm 

ET.

15 Aug 2014 14:09: Earlier today St Louis mayor Francis Slay {rejected}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee2dbde4b0f5010eedd8f7"> county 

attorney Bob McCulloch’s criticism of the governor for having changed police leadership 

in Ferguson.

McCulloch is heading up the county investigation into the killing of Michael Brown 

(there is also a federal investigation).

The St Louis Post-Dispatch reports that county executive Charlie Dooley, who appeared 

with the governor at the announcement of the police changeover Thursday, now is 

calling for McCulloch to be replaced:

[tweetbegin 500341832174153730 tweetend]

The south St Louis paper The Call sees old grievances at work:

[tweetbegin 500342363441483776 tweetend]

Update: Moveon.org has launched {a petition campaign}

<hyperlink="http://petitions.moveon.org/sign/appoint-a-special-prosecutor?

source=c.em.cp&r_by=11088158"> to replace McCulloch with a special prosecutor. The 

petition has more than 11,000 signatures. (h/t: {@jabuchanan}

<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/JABuchanan/status/500346378619338752">)

15 Aug 2014 13:52: Ferguson police have released video said to depict the alleged 

robbery described {in the incident report}

<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-

officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee159ee4b0d0d62bdb71ab"> released 

earlier today.

Update: {view video here}

<hyperlink="http://www.stltoday.com/news/multimedia/videos/ferguson-police-

release-convenience-store-surveillance-video/html_9cdfc317-764d-5ccd-a574-

2c75d2d0c753.html"> on the St Louis Post-Dispatch site. We’ll work on embedding a 

viewable version below.

Update 2: the below version, via the {St Louis Fox station,}

<hyperlink="http://fox2now.com/2014/08/15/raw-video-surveillance-video-believed-

to-show-michael-brown-robbing-convenience-store/"> works, but there’s an ad:

15 aug 2014 13:44: Brown family: we are 'beyond outraged' at 'devious' police

The family of Michael Brown is “beyond outraged” at the “devious” conduct of police 

who are trying to “assassinate the character of their son,” according to a statement 

issued by three attorneys for the family:

[tweetbegin 500334583075069952 tweetend]

The statement reads:

“Michael Brown’s family is beyond outraged at the devious way the police chief has 

chosen to disseminate piecemeal information in a manner intended to assassinate the 

character of their son, following such a brutal assassination of his person in broad 

daylight.
There is nothing based on the facts that have been placed before us that can justify the 

execution style murder of their child by this police officer as he held his hands up, which 

is the universal sign of surrender.
The prolonged release of the officer’s name and then the subsequent alleged 

information regarding a robbery is the reason why the family and the local community 

have such distrust for the local law enforcement agencies.
It is no way transparent to release the still photographs alleged to be Michael Brown and 

refuse to release the photographs of the officer that executed him.
The police strategy of attempting to blame the victim will not divert our attention, from 

being focused on the autopsy, ballistics report and the trajectory of the bullets that 

caused Michael’s death and will demonstrate to the world this brutal execution of an 

unarmed teenager.”
Benjamin L Crump, Esq.
Anthony D. Gray, Esq.
Daryl D. Parks, Esq."

15 Aug 2014 13:19: Reporter Joel Currier of the St Louis Dispatch asks {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> police whether Dorian Johnson, named in the incident report released today as a “second suspect” in the alleged robbery, would be arrested. They say no:

[tweetbegin 500329941050093568 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 500329954828357632 tweetend]

15 Aug 2014 13:03: As our live blog coverage continues, here’s a summary of where things stand:

• Ferguson police declined to describe how and why Michael Brown, 18, was killed on 9 August, but they did {name the officer}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee23d0e4b06c461acbb585"> who shot him, Darren Wilson, a six-year veteran of the force.

• There was no comment on when an incident report in the killing would be released. Reporters {were told}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee29bfe4b0d0d62bdb71bf"> Wilson had left his home days ago.

• Ferguson police released a separate {incident report}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee159ee4b0d0d62bdb71ab"> of an alleged strongarm robbery at a convenience store minutes before Brown was killed, naming Brown as a suspect. The report included video stills appearing to show Brown standing over a store clerk.

• A lawyer for the Brown family {accused police}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee3821e4b06c461acbb5a6"> of “character assassination” against Brown. Residents accused police of using the stills as a {smokescreen}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee2b15e4b0d0d62bdb71c0"> to hide a greater crime.

• Missouri Governor Jay Nixon {called for a full investigation}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee34f8e4b0f5010eedd905"> of the killing of Michael Brown. “Nothing should deter figuring out how and why Michael Brown was killed,” Nixon said.

• Ron Johnson, the highway patrol captain in charge of security in Ferguson, said police on Friday night would reprise the community outreach credited with calming the streets Thursday. “You’re going to see a bunch of smiles, a bunch of hugs, a bunch of conversations,” Johnson {said.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/15/ferguson-police-officer-michael-brown-darren-wilson#block-53ee3279e4b0d0d62bdb71c6">
