Title: The ghost of Mike Brown: why must a dead black child defend his right to life?
Author: Steven W Thrasher
ArticleText:
Mike Brown is currently engaged in one of the most difficult, but common – for black men, anyway – forms of criminal defense in the American criminal justice system: he is engaged in The Ultimate Defense.

Granted, it’s rather hard for him to wield The Ultimate Defense effectively, as the unarmed teenager was killed over the weekend – shot dead by a police officer in Ferguson, {Missouri.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/missouri"> But that’s the cruel irony of The Ultimate Defense: it’s always invoked posthumously, when the defendant can’t really defend himself because …well, because he’s dead.

Why was he in the police car?, people will ask. Why did he run? If he’d just been a pliant enough, wouldn’t he still be alive?!

Brown’s prosecutors in the court of public opinion will nonetheless demand he defend himself against these charges because he was a black teenager. His killer will remain presumed innocent. But for Mike Brown, there was a collective presumption of his guilt by the Ferguson police ... and that of the Ferguson citizens who gathered to air their grievances about the shooting long before any rioting started – and the timing of this is important. As a St Louis community activist who talked to me on Monday put it, he knew something was amiss when the police stationed K-9 units at the protest at 9am protest on Sunday.

“I have never seen police dogs barking at us at a peaceful march before,” he said.

The dogs aren’t just present in historic images of Southern police intimidating civil rights protests. (St Louis, notably, is the largest city in Missouri which, via the eponymous Missouri Compromise, was the last slave state admitted to the union.) The dogs are also tied into how other burned-out northern industrial towns use harsh police tactics – like {the tear gas and rubber bullets fired at protestors on Monday night}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/michael-brown-shooting-ferguson-missouri-police-crack-down-protesters"> – to keep their marginalized peoples from erupting, and how northern and southern tension merge in St Louis, smack in the middle of the US.

[tweetbegin 499025925691170816 tweetend]

But such containment can’t last forever. I spent some time in St. Louis earlier this year reporting on {a racially-charged story}<hyperlink="http://www.buzzfeed.com/steventhrasher/how-college-wrestling-star-tiger-mandingo-became-an-hiv-scap"> and came away extremely depressed by how blighted huge swaths of the metro area are. Ferguson sits north of the city, not so far from where Pruitt-Igoe –the {most notoriously disastrous housing project built during Urban Renewal}<hyperlink="http://www.riverfronttimes.com/movies/the-pruitt-igoe-myth-an-urban-history-1251078/"> – once stood. It was abandoned and blown up less than 20 years after it broke ground. What remains nearby the now overgrown ruin, like what’s visible throughout much of metropolitan St Louis where black people live, is an “economy” based on fast-food restaurants, payday loan sharks, casinos and, inevitably, crime.

In such quarters of our nation, where men seem as likely to have contact with the criminal justice system as with the public education system, citizens often find themselves on the defensive with police.

The Ultimate Defense is the final step in how black men (or, in the cases of {Trayvon Martin,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trayvon-martin"> Jordan Davis, Mike Brown and many more, black children) try to navigate this uneasy relationship with law enforcement in the United States, which collectively assumes our guilt before, during and after alleged crimes occur. This presumption doesn’t die – even when one of us is killed by law enforcement.

The first step in navigating this assumed guilt is “the talk”. My father, who was {routinely harassed by police}<hyperlink="http://www.buzzfeed.com/steventhrasher/a-personal-and-political-history-of-the-afro"> when he was driving to college at night, had “the talk” with me when I was six or seven, explaining how people would automatically assume that I was up to no good, and would often even presume I was about to commit (or had just committed) a crime.

I’d never heard white people discuss “the talk” until George Zimmerman killed Trayvon Martin, when some conservatives started having strong ideas about {how “the talk” could be altered for the benefit of white people.}<hyperlink="http://takimag.com/article/the_talk_nonblack_version_john_derbyshire/print#axzz3A7M8Mddk"> But I’ve heard endless variations of “the talk” among black folks – perhaps the most alarmingly when I was investigating police profiling in New York City in 2011. That’s when I learned the term “stop and frisk virginity”: black and Latino boys, as young as 10, would brag about who’d lost theirs or who was still a virgin.

Having a police officer act out his presumption of your guilt, it seems, is so ubiquitous – even today – that it’s a rite of passage toward manhood for these black and brown boys.

Their understanding is rooted in a harsh reality. In New York City, where I live and where Eric Garner was recently {choked to death during an arrest,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/01/eric-garner-nypd-chokehold-homicide"> people of color are thought to be more guilty of crimes and therefore {more likely to be stopped.}<hyperlink="http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/summons-broken-windows-racial-disparity-garner-article-1.1890567"> And while black and brown New Yorkers are {stopped exponentially more often,}<hyperlink="http://www.villagevoice.com/2011-09-21/news/young-mens-initiative-bloomberg-white-mayor-s-burden/full/"> the NYPD’s own data “demonstrate slightly higher rates of contraband yield” from white people than Hispanics or blacks. 

In Ferguson, as in New York, {black citizens are also far more likely to be stopped by cops,}<hyperlink="http://www.buzzfeed.com/jimdalrympleii/blacks-overwhelmingly-get-stopped-by-the-police-in-ferguson"> even though the Attorney General’s office reports that “whites are actually more likely to have contraband”.

It takes micro-defenses, if you will, to manage these daily assumptions of guilt, whether you’re {a teen stopped on the street,}<hyperlink="http://www.thenation.com/article/170413/stopped-and-frisked-being-fking-mutt-video"> a {shopper followed in a store,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/barneys-racial-profiling-settlement"> or a {Harvard professor arrested for entering your own house.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jul/21/henry-louis-gates-jr-arrest-harvard"> But a lack of habeas corpus is easier to fight with breath in your corpus. Lacking that, you need The Ultimate Defense.

Why were you wearing a hoodie? And walking through a gated community while black? Those are the kinds of questions Trayvon Martin had to ultimately defend himself against posthumously, despite the fact the unarmed 17 year-old was killed by a gun wielding maniac (who’d eventually walk away free and {later harm women}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/26/george-zimmerman-possession-five-guns-arrest">). Trayvon must have done something to deserve his death.

Why were you playing your music so loud? Don’t you know you’d still be alive if you had your music quieter? Ultimately, Jordan Davis had to defend himself for that. One jury {couldn’t decide}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/19/florida-juror-loud-music-killer-michael-dunn"> if Davis’s right to life trumped Michael Dunn’s right to “stand his ground” at a gas station. Jordan must have done something to deserve his death.

And now, Mike Brown’s ghost has to similarly invoke The Ultimate Defense. Sadly, the weight of all of this is being born by Mike Brown’s family, who have to simultaneously proffer The Ultimate Defense to a skeptical public: that their son, alive last week, had the right to live to see this one.
TheShitBetween: The assumption that black people must be guilty of something lies behind the Ferguson shooting, and the police reaction

Title: Morning Mail: Palmer on Chinese 'mongrels'; Assange to leave embassy
Author: Dave Earley
ArticleText:
Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – {sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">

Ferguson
We have {live reports from Ferguson, Missouri this morning,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-national-guard-protests-updates?CMP=ema_1731"> where {the governor has called in national guard troops}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-michael-brown-national-guard-deployed?CMP=ema_1731"> after the most intense violence since the shooting of unarmed teenager Michael Brown.

Brown’s family says the {autopsy shows the 18-year-old was trying to surrender, and was shot “at least” six times and was ultimately killed by a bullet to the head.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/michael-brown-autopsy-teenager-surrendering-ferguson?CMP=ema_1731">

{President Barack Obama has been briefed amid pressure for an urgent federal response, }<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/obama-briefed-ferguson-pressure-federal-response?CMP=ema_1731"> and is due to speak on the crisis this morning. {Follow the live blog as it happens.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-national-guard-protests-updates?CMP=ema_1731">

Reporters Rory Carroll and Jon Swaine write how {Missouri’s days of unrest have exposed the stark reality of a segregated society, and the divisions at the heart of America’s cities.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/16/ferguson-michael-brown-unrest-reality-segregated-society?CMP=ema_1731">

Writing for Comment is free, Gary Younge says {nobody in their right mind wants more violent protests, but in Ferguson the violence of the state created the violence of the street.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/18/ferguson-violence-martin-luther-king-michael-brown?CMP=ema_1731">

Finally, {Hands up: the message from Ferguson - in pictures.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2014/aug/18/hands-up-the-message-from-ferguson-in-pictures?CMP=ema_1731">

Australian news and politics
• {Clive Palmer launched an angry tirade against Australia’s biggest trading partner on the ABC’s Q&A program last night, describing the Chinese government as “mongrels” who shoot their own people.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/19/clive-palmer-accuses-china-of-trying-to-steal-australias-natural-resources?CMP=ema_1731">

• {Asked on radio about the damage done to the NSW Liberal party by the Icac revelations, Tony Abbott says the ‘problem’ was Labor banning developer donations in the first place.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/icac-tony-abbott-says-problem-was-labor-banning-developer-donations?CMP=ema_1731">

• {The church’s response to abuse victims has been described as ‘a betrayal’}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/icac-tony-abbott-says-problem-was-labor-banning-developer-donations?CMP=ema_1731"> at the royal commission hearing on Monday, while David Marr writes from the hearings that {it’s a telling detail: the abused don’t swear on the Bible.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/when-the-abused-come-to-the-witness-box-they-dont-swear-on-the-bible?CMP=ema_1731">

• {Clive Palmer has announced plans to host an unofficial “world climate change convention” at his Sunshine Coast resort the day after the G20 summit ends in Brisbane, but won’t reveal who would attend.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/clive-palmer-to-host-world-climate-change-convention-at-his-resort?CMP=ema_1731">

• It’s been revealed {government scientists who ‘warned against’ dumping millions of tonnes of dredged sediment in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park were overruled.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/aug/18/government-scientists-warned-against-dumping-in-great-barrier-reef-park?CMP=ema_1731">

• After it emerged yesterday that {Tony Abbott is backing the closure of the renewable energy target for all new entrants,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/abbott-pushing-for-ret-to-be-capped-off-despite-impact-on-solar-industry?CMP=ema_1731"> despite the impact it would have on the solar industry, {plans for one of Australia’s largest solar power stations have been scrapped, citing uncertainty over the future of the RET.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/plans-for-one-of-australias-largest-solar-power-stations-scrapped?CMP=ema_1731">

• In Grogonomics, Greg Jericho says {Joe Hockey’s fuel gaffe may see him excised from big policy debates, because “his seeming cluelessness regarding progressive taxation suggests little hope of his being able to handle any much bigger policy issues”.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2014/aug/18/joe-hockeys-fuel-gaffe-may-see-him-excised-from-big-policy-debates?CMP=ema_1731">

• Writing for Guardian Australia, former prime minister {Malcolm Fraser says Australians fighting overseas should be stripped of their citizenship, and could face treachery charges using a little known part of the Crimes Act.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2014/aug/18/joe-hockeys-fuel-gaffe-may-see-him-excised-from-big-policy-debates?CMP=ema_1731">

Iraq
In Iraq, {a security spokesman say the crucial Mosul dam has been retaken from Isis jihadists,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/iraqi-kurdish-forces-recapture-mosul-dam-isis?CMP=ema_1731"> but fighting continues nearby. {Follow our live blog for the latest developments.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/middle-east-live/live/2014/aug/18/iraq-crisis-uk-mission-could-last-for-months-live-updates?CMP=ema_1731">

There were {more US air strikes to help the Kurds retake Mosul dam,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/17/us-ramps-up-iraq-air-strikes-kurdish-attack-dam?CMP=ema_1731"> but {Iraqis are angry at perceptions the US is defending the Kurdish city of Irbil, but leaving Baghdad to its own fate as Isis closes in.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/16/iraq-anger-us-air-force-defends-irbil-not-iraq-kurds-maliki?CMP=ema_1731">

The {US State Department has sanctioned senior Isis members, banning them from financial dealings in or with the United States.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/us-sanctions-isis-members-mosul-dam-strikes?CMP=ema_1731">

An analyst whose Syrian home has seen some of its bloodiest excesses, {explains the dramatic surge of Isis: “a portrait of the menace that is sweeping my homeland”.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/16/isis-salafi-menace-jihadist-homeland-syria?CMP=ema_1731">

{Follow our live blog for all the latest updates from Iraq as they happen.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/middle-east-live/live/2014/aug/18/iraq-crisis-uk-mission-could-last-for-months-live-updates?CMP=ema_1731">

Around the world
• {Julian Assange has announced he will leave the Ecuadorian embassy ‘soon’,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/aug/18/julian-assange-confirms-leave-embassy-soon?CMP=ema_1731"> but dismisses reports it is to give himself up to authorities.

• {Gaza truce is set to end, but the Israeli delegation still pushing for demilitarisation of strip and hoping for an extension to the truce with Hamas.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/gaza-ceasefire-expires-israel-hamas?CMP=ema_1731">

• It’s been found an {Indonesian ferry that sank had no navigation gear,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/indonesia-ferry-survivors-tourist-boat?CMP=ema_1731"> after {survivors swam for six hours to safety and drank their own urine to survive.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/two-britons-swim-six-hours-boat-sinks-indonesia?CMP=ema_1731">

• {A young woman forced to give birth by caesarean section after being denied an abortion in Ireland became pregnant after she was raped.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ireland-woman-forced-caesarean-pregnant-rape-friend?CMP=ema_1731">

• Jessica Valenti writes: {A pregnant, suicidal rape victim fought Ireland’s new abortion law. The law won}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/18/pregnant-suicidal-victim-ireland-abortion-law?CMP=ema_1731">

More from around the internet
• Among the most viewed on the Guardian this morning: {Daniel Radcliffe says, ‘If people are speculating about your sexuality, then you’re doing OK’}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/17/-sp-daniel-radcliffe-speculating-sexuality-harry-potter?CMP=ema_1731">

• {Australia and Indonesia have concluded an agreement to patch up differences over allegations of Australia spying on Indonesia,}<hyperlink="http://click.mail.theguardian.com/?qs=3cda9422e94d2c4fe815e2a6d7d0f2b167c30ba839edcc8710be1f5a11304605"> the Australian reports.

• {The Commonwealth Bank has rewarded the bosses of scandal-ridden financial planning division,}<hyperlink="http://www.smh.com.au/business/cba-rewards-bosses-of-scandalridden-financial-planning-division-20140818-105buz.html%20?CMP=ema_1731"> the SMH reports.

• {Former treasurer Wayne Swan has described former friend and PM Kevin Rudd as ‘vengeful’ and ‘unstable’,}<hyperlink="http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/extreasurer-wayne-swan-gives-formerfriend-and-colleague-kevin-rudd-one-hell-of-a-rev/news-story/5ac038e51bf3970377a5dfddeab5d982?CMP=ema_1731"> the Courier-Mail reports.

One last thing
{This would be a sweet job for the right candidate. Cambridge University is offering a PhD in chocolate. How does more than three years of full-time chocolate sound? Delicious.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2014/aug/17/phd-chocolate-cambridge-university?CMP=ema_1731">

Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed or any errors, let me know on Twitter {@earleyedition}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/earleyedition"> and I’ll update this page.

Sign up
Get the {Morning Mail direct to your inbox before 8am every day by signing up here.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">
TheShitBetween: Guardian Australia’s morning news briefing from around the web

Title: Morning Mail: Iraq's PM forced out, new security laws 'criminalise journalism'
Author: Mary Hamilton
ArticleText:
Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – {sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">

Iraq
{Nouri al-Maliki has been forced out as Iraq’s prime minister}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email"> in a bid to end deadlock in Baghdad over the crisis in the country’s north.

We have {a profile of his replacement, Haider al-Abadi, who spent much of his life in exile in Britain}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/haider-al-abadi-profile-iraqs-next-prime-minister"> before returning after the 2003 invasion.

{The US has announced it will directly arm the militia forces of Iraqi Kurdistan,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/us-arm-peshmerga-iraq-kurdistan-isis"> in a bid to thwart the Isis militant offensive.

A senior Pentagon planning officer has said {the air strikes carried out over the weekend will have only a minimal impact on Isis forces.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/us-air-strikes-iraq-isis-minimal-impact-pentagon">

We have {live updates on the situation overnight.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/11/iraq-crisis-us-air-strikes-help-kurds-retake-territory-live-updates">

Australian news and politics
• {The Abbott government’s looming national security changes will “criminalise journalists and journalism”,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/australias-national-security-proposals-will-criminalise-journalists-says-union"> the media union has warned.

• {It’s a bad flu year: cases in Australia are more than double last year’s number.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/11/flu-cases-in-australia-more-than-double-last-years-number">

• {Cuts to higher education funding will hit less prestigious universities harder}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/11/flu-cases-in-australia-more-than-double-last-years-number"> because of their greater reliance on Commonwealth grants.

• At Icac, {Liberal MP Tim Owen has described being given a wad of money by the Newcastle mayor.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/icac-liberal-mp-tells-how-newcastle-mayor-gave-him-wad-of-money">

• {Suspended football coach James Hird disagreed with Essendon’s request for an Asada hearing into suspected doping,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/aug/11/james-hird-i-disagreed-with-essendons-asada-request"> the hearing was told yesterday.

• {The Australian has attacked the Press Council and its chairman Julian Disney,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/aug/11/news-corp-attacks-australian-press-council-and-its-chairman"> saying it has lost confidence in the body after its handling of a complaint about columns by Troy Bramston.

Gaza
Tens of thousands of people have returned to their homes amid a tenuous ceasefire in Gaza, {where the UN says the level of destruction is unprecedented.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/damage-gaza-homes-israel-hamas-conflict">

Among the families returning are children: {a “traumatised generation” whose response to this war could create “a new generation of enemies”,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/gaza-children-israel-new-generation-enemies-najia-warshagha"> according to a GCMHP psychiatrist.

We take a look at {the UN schools hit by the conflict.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/08/-sp-gaza-israeli-strikes-unrwa-schools">

Owen Jones writes on {the rise of anti-Jewish hatred.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/08/-sp-gaza-israeli-strikes-unrwa-schools">

Around the world
• {Protesters in Ferguson, a suburb of St Louis in the US, have demanded murder charges against a police officer}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/st-louis-protesters-officer-teenager"> who shot dead an unarmed teenager over the weekend.

• {Iran has banned permanent contraception in an attempt to boost population growth.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/iran-ban-permanent-contraception-population-growth">

• {Ukrainian forces are preparing to recapture Donetsk from rebels.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/ukraine-prepare-recapture-donetsk-luhansk">

• {BuzzFeed has been valued at more than three times the Washington Post}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/aug/11/buzzfeed-valued-at-three-times-washington-post"> after a new round of funding.

• {Veteran Game of Thrones actor JJ Murphy has died four days into filming.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/aug/11/game-of-thrones-actor-jj-murphy-dies-four-days-into-filming">

More from around the internet
• Among the most viewed on the Guardian this morning: {Daniel Radcliffe admits he’s not very good in the Harry Potter films.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/11/daniel-radcliffe-admits-hes-not-very-good-harry-potter-films">

• {Khaled Sharrouf’s brother has said Australians should forget about the shocking image of his young nephew}<hyperlink="http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/boys-uncle-says-forget-about-photo-of-severed-head-20140811-102t0t.html"> holding the severed head of a Syrian soldier, the SMH reports.

• {The boy’s grandfather says he is “gutted” by the image and has called on the government to act,}<hyperlink="http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/defence/jihads-child-soldiers-spark-calls-for-action-on-extremists/story-e6frg8yo-1227021107132"> the Australian reports.

• In the wake of baby Gammy’s plight, News.com.au {reports on the laws that prevent migrant children with Down’s syndrome and other disabilities from settling in Australia.}<hyperlink="http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/real-life/baby-gammy-isnt-the-only-one-the-ugly-law-shaming-australia/news-story/02b91be7758e5090c03e50910a7391c6">

• Acoss has called for {a radical welfare overhaul to replace all working-age payments and pensions with a single basic payment}<hyperlink="http://www.canberratimes.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/acoss-call-for-single-welfare-payment-to-cover-life-essentials-20140811-3divn.html"> to cover “life’s essentials”, the Canberra Times reports.

• {A young Liberal member has been forced to resign from his post at Swinburne University Liberal Club after posting homophobic and sexist comments on Facebook,}<hyperlink="http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/liberal-party-hit-by-another-social-media-controversy-after-members-homophobic-comments-20140811-102s7h.html?rand=1469754"> the Age reports.

• The Peabody Energy chief executive {has called on coal producers to spend more time and money fighting symbolic movements against the industry,}<hyperlink="http://www.afr.com/business/mining/coal/coal-always-wins-and-will-stay-no1-says-carbon-king-boyce-20140811-jekle"> the AFR reports.

• {A children’s soccer team in NSW has handed back sponsorship money from a coal company,}<hyperlink="https://newmatilda.com/2014/08/11/kids-footy-club-hands-back-sponsorship-cash-coal-company/"> New Matilda reports.

• {Businesses in Sydney will be forced to vote in the next election for lord mayor,}<hyperlink="http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/moore-under-fire-its-clover-and-out-as-businesses-to-get-vote/story-fni0cx12-1227021140356"> in a move which is expected to end Clover Moore’s decade-long reign, the Daily Telegraph reports.

• Seven News has {an exclusive report on the KKK in North Carolina.}<hyperlink="http://au.news.yahoo.com/nsw/a/24686970/rare-access-to-shameful-relic-from-the-past/">

• {A cannabis factory has been found in the grounds of a mental health hospital in Wales,}<hyperlink="http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2014/08/12/dope-crop-found-welsh-hospital"> SBS reports.

One last thing
{Boom and dust: the uncertain future for the mining town built by Rio Tinto now that its refinery has closed.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/11/-sp-boom-to-dust-uncertain-future-for-town-run-by-rio-tinto">

Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed or any errors, let me know on Twitter {@newsmary}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/newsmary"> and I’ll update this page.

Sign up
Get the {Morning Mail direct to your inbox before 8am every day by signing up here.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">
TheShitBetween: Guardian Australia’s morning news briefing from around the web

Title: Morning Mail: Iraqis escape mountain; Gammy's parents interviewed; new Gaza ceasefire
Author: Mary Hamilton
ArticleText:
Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – {sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">

Iraq
{More than 20,000 of the 40,000 people trapped by jihadists on a mountaintop in northern Iraq have escaped}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/kurdish-rebels-yazidi-iraq-isis"> in the past 24 hours, aided by Kurdish rebels who crossed from Syria to rescue them.

The breakthrough {coincided with US air raids on Isis fighters in the area on Saturday}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/iraq-yazidi-isis-jihadists-islamic-state-kurds">; {US fighter jets and drones hit Isis vehicles and artillery again five times on Sunday,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/us-air-strikes-isis-iraq-yazidi-refugees"> as cargo planes continued to drop meals and fresh water.

{Tony Abbott on Saturday offered Australia’s assistance to the US for humanitarian air drops.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/09/australia-preparing-to-join-iraq-air-campaign-says-tony-abbott">

Isis {has released a new propaganda video purporting to show the group’s military gains in Iraq.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2014/aug/10/isis-propaganda-video-iraqis-islamic-state-yazidis-video">

Australian news and politics
• {Baby Gammy’s Australian parents wanted a refund and would have aborted him,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/baby-gammy-parents-interview-aborted-downs-syndrome-australia"> according to a Channel Nine interview aired last night.

• {113,000 people a year under 30 will face a six-month wait for unemployment benefits under the government’s proposed budget changes,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/wait-for-the-dole-for-113000-under-30s-will-have-deeply-disturbing-effect"> and social services advocates have warned they face “deeply disturbing” knock-on effects.

• {Tony Abbott is under pressure to put climate change on the G20 meeting agenda,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/tony-abbott-under-pressure-to-put-climate-change-on-g20-meeting-agenda"> with a group of medical scientists warning Australians face “serious health risks” if the issue isn’t urgently tackled.

• {Education minister Christopher Pyne has warned against presenting all-or-nothing reforms to the Senate,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/christopher-pyne-says-all-or-nothing-stance-will-not-work-in-senate"> and acknowledged the government’s higher education changes will face a tough fight.

• {Web domain names that include the phrase “Abbott lies” were registered in the name of the Liberal party}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/abbott-lies-web-domain-names-registered-in-liberal-party-name"> on the date of the government’s first budget.

• {The NRL could introduce a rookie draft in 2017.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/aug/10/nrl-could-introduce-rookie-draft-in-2017">

Gaza
{Israel and Hamas have agreed to another 72-hour ceasefire starting at midnight local time,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/gaza-israel-hamas-agree-72-hour-ceasefire-egyptian-proposal"> in a last-ditch attempt to avert a lengthy war in Gaza.

The agreement comes after {Hamas officials threatened a “major escalation” of rocket strikes against Israel if demands for the lifting of a blockade and the release of prisoners were not met.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/09/gaza-hamas-threatens-escalation-rocket-strikes-israel">

US support for Israel remains strong, {though relations between the Obama administration and Binyamin Netanyahu’s government have been driven to a new low by the conflict.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/united-states-israel-strained-relations-gaza">

Paul Mason {writes about the propaganda wars occurring in Gaza, as information flows through social media and radio.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/10/truth-propaganda-foes-gaza-war-independent-journalism">

{Islamic groups have threatened to boycott the SMH over Mike Carlton’s departure}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/aug/09/islamic-groups-threaten-smh-boycott-over-mike-carltons-departure"> in the wake of a controversial column on Gaza.

Around the world
• {Uganda has held its first pride rally after its anti-gay law was overturned.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/09/uganda-first-gay-pride-rally-law-overturned">

• {Nascar driver Tony Stewart has hit and killed a fellow racer.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/aug/10/nascar-crash-tony-stewart">

• {An unarmed 18-year-old black man was shot and killed by police in Ferguson, St Louis,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/police-fatal-shooting-black-teenager-angry-crowd-st-louis-suburb"> prompting hundreds of protesters to take to the streets.

• {A nine-year-old boy in Florida has fought off an alligator.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/florida-boy-fights-off-alligator">

• {Turkish prime minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan looks set to become the country’s first directly elected president.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/turkey-presidential-election-ergodan">

• {New York is seeing a spectacular surge in whale and shark numbers in its waters.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/whale-shark-numbers-surge-new-york-waters">

• {Lennox Lewis’s former manager has revealed that she is undergoing gender reassignment and now lives as Kellie Maloney.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/aug/10/kellie-maloney-boxing-transgender">

• We have {live coverage of the final round of the US PGA championship}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2014/aug/10/us-pga-championship-2014-final-round-rory-mcilroy-live">; Australia’s Jason Day was three shots off the lead going into the final round.

More from around the internet
• Among the most viewed on the Guardian this morning: {pictures of the wet weather in the UK as Hurricane Bertha hit yesterday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2014/aug/10/bertha-in-pictures">

• {A controversial deal to allow Australia to send refugees to Cambodia could be signed this week,}<hyperlink="http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/cambodian-deal-to-resettle-asylum-seekers-imminent-20140810-102ht3.html"> the SMH reports.

• {Sick asylum seekers on Christmas Island are being treated by teleconferencing after damning evidence of the state of medical services in immigration detention,}<hyperlink="http://www.canberratimes.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/sick-asylum-seekers-treated-via-video-conferencing-20140810-102gh6.html"> Fairfax reports.

• The Daily Telegraph reports {on the shocking image of the 7-year-old Sydney-born son of Khaled Sharrouf holding up the decapitated head of a slain Syrian soldier.}<hyperlink="http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/the-photo-that-will-shock-the-world-jihadist-khaled-sharroufs-son-7-holds-severed-head/story-fni0cx12-1227019897582">

• {Tony Abbott has arrived in the Netherlands to meet his Dutch counterpart Mark Rutte in the wake of the MH17 disaster,}<hyperlink="http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2014/08/11/tony-abbott-touches-down-netherlands"> SBS reports.

• {8,000 more jobs hang in the balance at the Australian Taxation Office,}<hyperlink="http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/more-jobs-pain-for-tax-office-20140810-102iua.html"> the Canberra Times reports.

• {A former federal Labor MP was on a list of secret KGB informants,}<hyperlink="http://www.theage.com.au/national/agent-albert-mp-listed-as-secret-kgb-informant-in-russian-archives-20140810-102jtm.html"> the SMH reports.

• New Matilda reports that {the Whitehouse Institute gave away an Indigenous scholarship for a course that never ran.}<hyperlink="http://newmatilda.com/2014/08/10/whitehouse-awarded-aboriginal-scholarship-course-never-ran">

• {Woolworths has opened its first online-only “dark” store,}<hyperlink="http://www.afr.com/p/business/companies/woolworths_opens_first_online_only_PBJuHkStjqI3iEjcUOvdSI"> the AFR reports.

One last thing
{Alain de Botton’s philosophical crowd-pleasing distilled in quotes:}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2014/aug/10/alain-de-botton-in-quotes-the-news-promotes-a-toxic-society-of-envy"> “The news promotes a toxic society of envy.”

Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed or any errors, let me know on Twitter {@newsmary}<hyperlink="http://www.twitter.com/newsmary"> and I’ll update this page.

Sign up
Get the {Morning Mail direct to your inbox before 8am every day by signing up here.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">
TheShitBetween: Guardian Australia’s morning news briefing from around the web

Title: Morning Mail: US troops land in Iraq; Hockey on poverty and cars
Author: Mary Hamilton
ArticleText:
Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – {sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">

Iraq
{US ground troops have landed on Mt Sinjar in Iraq to evacuate the remaining 30,000 Yazidis}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/us-ground-troops-direct-role-evacuate-yazidis-iraq"> stranded there by militant group Isis.

{The US is likely to arm Iraq’s new government with weapons to fight Isis,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/iraq-us-arms-weapons-isis-new-government"> and {Britain is helping to transport ammunition from eastern European countries to Kurdish forces.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/aug/13/british-forces-helping-transport-ammunition-to-kurdish-force-iraq">

The US has also {rejected former prime minister Nouri al-Maliki’s bid to keep power in favour of Haider al-Abadi}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/us-iraq-ignore-maliki-prime-minister">; we have {more on the power struggle in Baghdad and Maliki’s fight for survival.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/iraq-abadi-maliki-baghdad-prime-minister-struggle">

Australian defence minister {David Johnston yesterday doubled down on Abbott’s statement that he would not rule out military action,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/defence-minister-makes-no-rule-in-rule-out-guarantee-on-troops-to-iraq"> saying he would not get into a “rule-in rule-out guarantee game”.

We have {live updates on the situation overnight.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/middle-east-live/live/2014/aug/13/iraq-crisis-us-and-uk-step-up-involvement-live-updates">

Australian news and politics
• {Joe Hockey has lashed out at “hysteria” over comments he made yesterday about the fuel excise increase,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/money/2014/aug/13/joe-hockey-defends-his-poor-people-dont-drive-very-far-comments"> saying it would hit high-income earners hardest because “the poorest people either don’t have cars or actually don’t drive very far in most cases”.

• {Cardiovascular disease is worse in regional and rural Australia, according to new analysis}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/ng-interactive/2014/aug/14/-sp-cardiovascular-disease-worse-regional-rural-australia-map"> by the Heart Foundation.

• {Australian researchers studying zebrafish have made one of the most significant discoveries ever in stem cell research.}<hyperlink="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/aug/13/stem-cell-research-gets-huge-boost-from-australian-zebrafish-discovery">

• Advocates say {disability is being criminalised through the treatment of people with foetal alcohol spectrum disorders}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/13/disability-criminalised-treatment-foetal-alcohol-spectrum-disorders-australia"> within Australia’s justice system.

• {Australia’s defence abuse taskforce does not know how many offenders are still serving in the military.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/australian-defence-abuse-taskforce-doesnt-know-how-many-offenders-are-still-serving">

Around the world
• Nigeria fears {a fourth frontline in the fight against the Ebola epidemic after an infected man has landed in Lagos,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/ebola-nigerian-capital"> Africa’s most populous city.

• {Israel and Gaza have agreed to extend their ceasefire for five days despite rocket fire}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/gaza-conflict-israel-hamas-extend-ceasefire">; we have {an interview with Gaza’s top bomb disposal expert, just days before he died.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/-sp-gaza-bomb-disposal-expert-bomb-dead">

• The {death toll from conflict in Ukraine has doubled in the past fortnight,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/un-escalating-trend-violence-aid-convoy-death-toll"> topping 2,000; {Ukraine has refused to admit a Russian aid convoy amid concerns it is a prelude to invasion.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/russia-aid-convoy-reach-ukraine-within-hours">

• {Missouri police have apparently shot a second man in Ferguson,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/missouri-police-shoot-man-city-teenager-killed"> where {protests have been continuing after an unarmed black 18-year-old was shot dead by police last weekend.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/ferguson-missouri-shooting-michael-brown-civil-rights-police-brutality">

• {Two thirds of people with depression in Britain get no treatment.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/13/two-thirds-britons-not-treated-depression">

• {An American woman’s body has been found in a suitcase in Bali.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/american-woman-body-found-suitcase-bali">

More from around the internet
• Among the most viewed on the Guardian this morning: {abandoned venues from the 2004 Athens Olympics, ten years on.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/gallery/2014/aug/13/abandoned-athens-olympic-2004-venues-10-years-on-in-pictures">

• {The federal government is facing another veto as senators warn against boosting childcare funding as part of the paid parental leave scheme,}<hyperlink="http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/treasury/childcare-boost-faces-senate-veto/story-fn59nsif-1227023615268"> the Australian reports.

• {Harriet Wran, the daughter of former NSW premier Neville Wran, has been charged with murder after a double stabbing,}<hyperlink="http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/neville-wrans-daughter-harriet-wran-charged-with-murder-of-redfern-drug-dealer-20140813-103rk1.html"> the SMH reports.

• The Conversation {speaks to experts on the state of the Great Barrier Reef after two reports into its declining health.}<hyperlink="http://theconversation.com/the-state-of-the-great-barrier-reef-experts-respond-30450">

• {Australia’s top income tax rate is nearing the level where it would hurt economic growth, according to visiting US economics Nobel laureate Ed Prescott,}<hyperlink="http://www.afr.com/p/national/ed_prescott_says_top_tax_rate_killing_psTfBlCsgwrvQ0QetoxLxJ"> the AFR reports.

• {Paul Little has denied a rift between Essendon and coach James Hird,}<hyperlink="http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/paul-little-denies-rift-between-essendon-and-james-hird-declares-he-will-absolutely-coach-in-2015/story-fni5f6kv-1227023468853"> the Herald Sun reports.

• {A 10-year-old Victorian boy has written to Tony Abbott to ask why his mums can’t marry,}<hyperlink="http://au.news.yahoo.com/vic/a/24706633/vic-boy-10-challenges-pms-stand-on-gay-marriage-in-letter/"> 7 News reports.

One last thing
{A spider has photobombed BBC News in Scotland.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/aug/13/spider-photobombs-bbc-reporting-scotland-news">

Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed or any errors, let me know on Twitter {@newsmary}<hyperlink="http://www.twitter.com/newsmary"> and I’ll update this page.

Sign up
Get the {Morning Mail direct to your inbox before 8am every day by signing up here.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">

Title: Morning Mail: Iraq crisis, Robin Williams tributes, Icac resignations
Author: Mary Hamilton
ArticleText:
Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – {sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guardian-australia-morning-mail/2014/jun/24/-sp-guardian-australias-morning-mail-subscribe-by-email">

Iraq
{During a visit to London,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/tony-abbott-australia-military-action-iraq-isis"> {Tony Abbott has declined to rule out military action in northern Iraq,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/tony-abbott-australia-military-action-iraq-isis"> saying he was not prepared to stand aside in the face of a potential genocide.

Yesterday {opposition leader Bill Shorten said the case had not been made for sending Australian troops back to Iraq,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/no-case-made-for-australian-troops-in-iraq-says-bill-shorten"> as {US secretary of state John Kerry insisted US combat forces would not re-enter the country.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/john-kerry-insists-us-iraq-not-involve-combat-troops">

Iran {has put its support behind Maliki’s successor Haider al-Abadi}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/iran-supports-successor-nouri-al-maliki-iraq"> as Iraqi prime minister.

We have {live coverage of events overnight}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/middle-east-live/live/2014/aug/12/iraq-crisis-kerry-urges-abadi-to-form-new-government-swiftly-live-updates"> including the ongoing plight of the Yazidis, and {analysis of how Isis has exposed the military vulnerability of the Kurdish peshmerga.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/islamic-state-peshmerga-vulnerability-kurdish-isis">

Australian news and politics
• {Liberal MPs Tim Owen and Andrew Cornwell have both resigned from NSW parliament}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/liberal-mps-tim-owen-and-andrew-cornwell-quit-after-icac-admissions"> after admitting at Icac that they received money from property developers.

• {A Liberal backbench MP has called for a warrant scheme for access to metadata retained under new national security laws,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/data-retention-liberal-backbencher-calls-for-metadata-warrant-requirement"> saying people should be able to know who is accessing their data.

• {Australia is close to a refugee resettlement deal with Cambodia,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/australia-close-to-refugee-resettlement-deal-with-cambodia-reports-claim"> according to Cambodian media reports.

• {Australia has signed on to cooperate with American ballistic missile defence systems in north Asia,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/australia-embraces-missile-naval-ties-us-defence-pact"> and welcomed the larger US marine presence in Darwin.

• {A migrant worker program will go ahead in the Northern Territory despite fears of conflicts}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/migrant-worker-program-to-go-ahead-in-nt-on-top-of-jobseeker-relocation-grant"> with a new incentive scheme offering unemployed Australians up to $9,000 to move for work.

Robin Williams
{Tributes have poured in}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/12/robin-williams-death-online-tributes"> after {the death of 63-year-old actor and comedian Robin Williams yesterday.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/12/robin-williams-found-dead-personal-assistant-officials-say">

Comedian {Russell Brand writes about the “divine madness” that drove him: “a refinement of energy that could turn as easily to destruction as creativity”.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/12/russell-brand-robin-williams-divine-madness-broken-world">

Dean Burnett writes {a timely reminder that depression and suicide are not selfish,}<hyperlink="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2014/aug/12/robin-williams-suicide-and-depression-are-not-selfish"> and Alastair Campbell writes {on how his tragic death highlights how little we understand about depression.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/12/robin-williams-tragedy-understand-depression">

{In this 2010 interview, Robin Williams speaks about his struggles with alcohol, drugs and mental illness}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/sep/20/robin-williams-worlds-greatest-dad-alcohol-drugs">: “I ask if he feels happier now, and he says softly, ‘I think so. And not afraid to be unhappy. That’s OK too. And then you can be like, all is good. And that is the thing, that is the gift.’”

Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw {remembers Robin Williams as a remarkable performer,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/12/robin-williams-a-comedic-genius-a-staggering-talent-and-a-big-heart"> and we take {a look back at his career in clips}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/12/robin-williams-a-career-in-clips"> and {some of his best-loved gags.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/12/robin-williams-best-loved-gags">

Around the world
• In Gaza {hopes are rising of and end to the month-long war, with Hamas and other groups cautiously optimistic}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/gaza-war-hamas-israel-peace-ceasefire"> that a deal could be made with Israel before the current ceasefire ends.

• {Police fired wooden bullets into crowds during protests over the killing of unarmed teenager Michael Brown by police in Ferguson.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/missouri-police-wooden-bullets-protest-michael-brown">

• {The World Health Organisation has allowed experimental, unlicensed drugs and vaccines to be used in tackling the Ebola outbreak in west Africa.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/12/world-health-organisation-allow-unlicensed-ebola-drugs-west-africa">

• {A Russian aid convoy is heading to the Ukraine amid doubts over what its lorries contain.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/russian-aid-convoy-ukraine-humanitarian">

• {A prisoner who has been detained in}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/aug/12/guantanamo-prisoner-publish-memoirs-diary-mohamedou-ould-slahi"> Guantánamo since 2002 but never charged with a crime will publish an account of his experiences next yeardetailing the torture he has suffered.

More from around the internet
• Among the most viewed on the Guardian this morning after tributes to Robin Williams: {an iPhone trick that means you can avoid Facebook messenger and keep chatting.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/aug/12/iphone-trick-facebook-messenger-chat">

• Most of the Australian media splashes on Robin Williams’ death this morning.

• {A new visa deal could allow more Australians to live and work in the UK,}<hyperlink="http://www.couriermail.com.au/travel/travel-advice/new-visa-deal-to-allow-australians-to-work-in-great-britain/story-fnihr5wo-1227022244064"> the Courier Mail reports.

• {Hundreds of bodies in East Perth could be dug up as part of a major development project,}<hyperlink="http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/east-perth-the-site-of-australias-biggest-exhumation-20140812-zt1pc.html"> WA Today reports.

• {The mother of a toddler allegedly raped by a carer says she reported her suspicions to Families SA two years before he was arrested,}<hyperlink="http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/mother-of-child-allegedly-raped-by-arrested-families-sa-carer-says-she-reported-her-suspicions-to-agency-before-his-arrest-but-was-ignored/story-fni6uo1m-1227022370146"> the Adelaide Advertiser reports.

• {A new app will let job seekers on welfare send their CVs to dozens of federal MPs simultaneously,}<hyperlink="http://newmatilda.com/2014/08/12/dole-bludgers-revenge"> meeting the Coalition’s 40-jobs-a-month requirements in minutes, New Matilda reports.

One last thing
{The editor of the Macquarie Dictionary on why “youse” deserves its place in the Australian language.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/books/australia-culture-blog/2014/aug/12/australias-national-dictionary-editor-on-the-heat-about-youse">

Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed or any errors, let me know on Twitter {@newsmary.}<hyperlink="http://www.twitter.com/newsmary">
TheShitBetween: Guardian Australia’s morning news briefing from around the web

Title: 21 things you need to know about BuzzFeed's success
Author: Elena Cresci
ArticleText:
1. It’s not just about lists
In the words of BuzzFeed’s editorial director Jack Shepherd: {“A list is just scaffolding for a story”}<hyperlink="http://www.newsrewired.com/2014/02/20/live-keynote-speech-from-jack-shepherd/"> – but BuzzFeed definitely isn’t just a load of lists. It also does news, long-form features and videos.

2. And it’s not just cats and gifs either ... but there are a lot of them on there
Because cats and gifs are great. *prepares to staunchly defend them in the comments*

3. BuzzFeed loves sloths a lot too

4. And corgis
[tweetbegin 439120010272067584 tweetend]

5. On a serious note: it’s set the tone for digital media
No, BuzzFeed didn’t invent the “listicle” and it didn’t invent quizzes. But since it launched in 2006, {BuzzFeed}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/buzzfeed"> has changed the digital landscape considerably.
From regional to national and international media, everyone’s trying to imitate it for one simple reason – what BuzzFeed does really does work. For example, i100 (the Independent’s viral news site) has an article called {The 12 ways in which Ukip is the gift that keeps on giving,}<hyperlink="http://i100.independent.co.uk/article/the-12-ways-in-which-ukip-is-the-gift-that-keeps-on-giving--l19bKyNYA"> WalesOnline has a list of {18 things you only remember if you went to university in Swansea in the 1990s}<hyperlink="http://www.walesonline.co.uk/lifestyle/fun-stuff/swansea-university-things-you-would-7544963"> ... even the Guardian has been known to publish the odd list every now and then.

6. It’s not about views, it’s about shares
[tweetbegin 436472506690457602 tweetend]

A whopping {75% of BuzzFeed’s traffic}<hyperlink="http://www.thedrum.com/news/2014/07/29/humour-nostalgia-and-value-buzzfeed-shares-its-branded-content-lessons"> comes from social media.

7. So they know exactly how to target social networks
How do you get Twitter to pay attention to you? You write about Twitter, of course. “{The 29 stages of a Twitterstorm}<hyperlink="http://www.buzzfeed.com/tomphillips/the-29-stages-of-a-twitterstorm">” is a classic example.

8. ... especially Pinterest
As far as social traffic is concerned, Facebook is where it’s at. But BuzzFeed’s {second biggest source of social traffic comes from Pinterest,}<hyperlink="http://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2014/07/17/nailed-it-buzzfeed-cracks-the-pinterest-code/"> a social network linked more with life and style content rather than news.

9. They’re pretty good at video too
{BuzzFeedVideo}<hyperlink="https://www.youtube.com/user/BuzzFeedVideo"> has more than 2m subscribers on YouTube.

10. And they know exactly how to get you to share their stuff
The reason those quizzes are so popular: “Oh I SO AM Hodor from Game of Thrones and I want all of my Facebook friends to know!”

{BuzzFeed UK’s editor Luke Lewis told The Drum}<hyperlink="http://www.thedrum.com/news/2014/03/25/there-s-hunger-political-content-s-fun-and-entertaining-luke-lewis-editor-buzzfeed">: “We appeal to human beings, not GoogleBots.” Part of the reason you’ll see extremely niche content ({26 things only emo kids will understand}<hyperlink="http://www.buzzfeed.com/jobarrow/only-emo-kids-understand">) is because people are far more likely to share if they identify strongly with it.

11. It all started with an email chain
This article from New York magazine explains {how the seeds of BuzzFeed were sown with one email thread}<hyperlink="http://nymag.com/news/features/buzzfeed-2013-4/">:
In 2001, [founder Jonah] Peretti, then 27, was supposed to be writing his master’s thesis but instead diverted himself by goofing off online. Nike was promoting a new customizable sneaker; Peretti ordered a pair imprinted with the wordsweatshop, prompting an amusing exchange of e-mails with a customer-­service representative. Peretti forwarded the chain to ten friends. It went forth and multiplied, {taking on irresistible}<hyperlink="http://www.shey.net/niked.html"> momentum as it was forwarded from in-box to in-box. Six weeks later, Peretti found himself on theToday show, debating a Nike spokesman about its labor practices.

12. And it grew from there
Peretti wanted to prove he could repeat the same kind of virality, and he’s succeeded. Nowadays, BuzzFeed boasts a monthly audience of more than 150 million and counting.

13. They’ve expanded pretty quickly
BuzzFeed now has offices all over the world, including London, Mumbai, Sydney and Paris.

14. BuzzFeedUK was born after Lewis {approached them with a mockup of what a British version of the site}<hyperlink="http://www.gorkana.com/news/consumer/little-black-book/gorkana-meetsbuzzfeed/"> could look like
We’re not sure if the mock up was anything like this though:
[tweetbegin 316101992592314368 tweetend]

15. They’ve had kudos and investment from some of the biggest names in the business ... including Rupert Murdoch
[tweetbegin 433704142683389952 tweetend]

16. They’re pretty serious about news – whether it’s breaking news ... 
[tweetbegin 498700186328502272 tweetend]

17. ... or investigative journalism
BuzzFeed has made a number of really clever hires in the last year to this end, including {Pulitzer prizewinner Mark Schoofs}<hyperlink="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/22/business/media/buzzfeed-hires-pulitzer-winner-to-head-investigative-unit.html"> to head up their investigative unit.

18. BuzzFeed is just going to get bigger and bigger with a little help from its {$50m (£30m) of new funding}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/aug/11/buzzfeed-funding-media-andreessen-horowitz">
The new funding comes from venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, which has backed the likes of Twitter and AirBnB.

19. It’s not without its controversy
Last month, BuzzFeed sacked its viral politics editor Benny Johnson after finding he had copied sentences and phrases {“word for word”}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jul/26/buzzfeed-sacks-editor-benny-johnson-plagiarism"> from other sites.

20. But they are very good at what they do
BuzzFeed has gone from a small viral lab based in New York to a huge global media and technology company – and it’s not even 10 years old yet.

21. Also: BuzzFeedUK has an office dog
[instabegin https://www.instagram.com/p/qyz-ozl56E/ instaend]
Phineas is otherwise known as BuzzFeed’s director of naps and bin sniffing.
TheShitBetween: A venture capital firm has just invested $50m (£30m) into the viral news site. Here’s why BuzzFeed is so successful
Notes: The word 'Ferguson' appears in one of the Twitter text embedded, not in the article itself.

Title: Ferguson crisis: Obama says 'young men of colour are left behind' – live updates
Author: Amanda Holpuch
ArticleText:
