18 Aug 2014 11:11: Medical examiner Dr Michael Baden, who conducted the preliminary autopsy and was the chief medical examiner in New York City, said it is common for families of people killed by police to seek a private autopsy because of distrust in government officials. He said that the chief medical examiner in St Louis is “an excellent forensic pathologist,” but emphasized the need to release information on the autopsy.

“What we found in New York City, is the sooner the information goes out, the sooner the family is talked to – the family has a right to know how their loved one died – this calms the community,” Baden said.

“Very simple things are found on day one of the autopsy,” he said. Baden said information about how many bullet wounds the victim received and how much suffering they endured, typically the primary concerns of the family, can be determined on day one.

18 Aug 2014 10:58: Michael Brown’s family, their attorneys and the medical examiner who {conducted a preliminary autopsy}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-national-guard-protests-updates#block-53f207bee4b0f5010eeddb0e"> on behalf of Brown’s family, are speaking to press at Greater St Mark Missionary Baptist Church in St Louis.

Attorney Benjamin Crump, who is representing the family of Michael Brown, said that more witness accounts were needed to provide the full story of Brown’s shooting.

“What does this preliminary account [the autopsy] tell us? That the witness accounts were true,” Crump said. “That he was shot multiple times.”

He said the family wanted a private autopsy performed because they did not want the only autopsy to be conducted by St Louis law enforcement agencies “– the same officials they think are responsible for executing their son in broad daylight,” said Crump.

He stressed that it was a preliminary report, but answered the family’s first question about their son’s death: “how many times was he shot?” He was shot at least six times, according to the autopsy.

18 Aug 2014 10:31

18 Aug 2014 10:17: The Guardian’s {Jon Swaine}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/jonswaine"> and {Rory Carroll}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/rorycarroll72"> are in Ferguson reporting on the protests. {Their latest dispatch}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-michael-brown-national-guard-deployed"> includes details on the use of high-pitched sirens and stun grenades during the overnight protests as people looted stores and vandalized buildings:

Police drove protesters with more gas northwards towards a burned out petrol station that was looted last Sunday. Some protesters smashed the windows of a hair salon and a storage facility as they passed. Then a burst of gunfire was heard over the road from the petrol station, sending people scrambling to the ground.
Protesters said they had no intention of backing down. “This is a revo-fucking-lution,” said DeAndre Smith, a 30-year-old barber. “Plain and simple, this is the revolution. The one everybody was waiting on. It happened like this. It’s the gain in culture by a people who want respect. African American people in this country.
“I been out here since day one. I was on the frontline. Mike Brown was the straw that broke the camel’s back. That’s when we said this is enough. That’s it.”
Following a standoff at the petrol station, police sent remaining demonstrators scrambling into side streets by speeding at them in armoured Swat trucks, firing yet more gas and smoke at people running away. The trucks continued driving up and down the main street doing this until it was cleared. As some reached a branch of Domino’s pizza, there were two more bursts of gunshots.

18 Aug 2014 10:04: Each of the at least six bullets shot at Michael Brown were fired at the front of his body, according preliminary autopsy results {reported by The New York Times on Sunday night.}<hyperlink="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/18/us/michael-brown-autopsy-shows-he-was-shot-at-least-6-times.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&version=LedeSumLargeMedia&module=a-lede-package-region&region=lede-package&WT.nav=lede-package&_r=1">

The bullets did not appear to be fired from close range, according to the report by Dr Michael M Baden, the former chief medical examiner for New York City who was flown into {Missouri}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/missouri"> at the request of Brown’s family. He said that the close range assessment could be amended if there is gunshot residue on Brown’s clothing, which Baden did not have access to.

Baden said more information was needed to determine {the context of the shooting.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-michael-brown-shot-multiple-times-autopsy-shows-including-in-head">

“This one here looks like his head was bent downward,” Baden said, indicating the wound at the very top of Brown’s head. “It can be because he’s giving up, or because he’s charging forward at the officer.”

Baden, Brown’s family and their attorney are set to host a press conference at 9:30am CST/10:30am ET.

18 Aug 2014 09:51: Ferguson {community members}<hyperlink="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/17/ferguson-protest-cleanup_n_5685588.html"> are cleaning up debris from the overnight protests and police action, which left gas canisters, broken bottles and bricks cluttering the streets.

In spite of a governor-determined 12am to 5am curfew, people were on the streets from Sunday night into early Monday morning. Some chanted “No justice! No curfew!” as police in armored tactical vehicles ordered them to disperse, {according to the AP.}<hyperlink="http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/governor-declares-emergency-sets-ferguson-curfew-25006363">

{Police fired teargas and rubber bullets into crowd,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-michael-brown-national-guard-deployed"> as some protesters threw gas cans back at police. Some protesters carried bricks and bottles through the streets to throw at officers, while others looted businesses. Officials said protesters also threw molotov cocktails, though people disputed these claims.

[tweetbegin 501355859461816320 tweetend]

18 Aug 2014 09:39: Welcome to our live coverage on the protests in Ferguson, Missouri. State governor Jay Nixon said early Monday morning that the National Guard {is to be deployed}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-michael-brown-national-guard-deployed"> to Ferguson following a week of protests in response to the shooting of an unarmed 18-year-old Michael Brown.

The announcement was made following the eighth, and most intense, night of unrest since Brown was killed on 9 August. {Nixon said in the order}<hyperlink="https://governor.mo.gov/news/archive/following-coordinated-attacks-civilians-and-law-enforcement-governor-nixon-signs"> that he was directing troops to the northern suburb of St Louis because of the “deliberate, coordinated and intensifying violent attacks on lives and property in Ferguson.”

“These violent acts are a disservice to the family of Michael Brown and his memory, and to the people of this community who yearn for justice to be served, and to feel safe in their own homes.”

As gunfire rang through the city on Sunday night and police used teargas and rubber bullets on crowds, {The New York Times}<hyperlink="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/18/us/michael-brown-autopsy-shows-he-was-shot-at-least-6-times.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&version=LedeSumLargeMedia&module=a-lede-package-region&region=lede-package&WT.nav=lede-package&_r=1"> reported the results of a preliminary autopsy of Brown’s body, showing that police officer Darren Wilson shot Brown at least six times, including twice in the head.

The Department of Justice said on Sunday it is taking the unusual step of ordering a third autopsy by a federal medical examiner. The agency is also leading a civil-rights investigation into the killing.

We’ll be providing updates as the story develops throughout the day.
TheShitBetween:
• Attorney general Eric Holder to travel to Ferguson
• Governor Jay Nixon {calls in national guard}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-michael-brown-national-guard-deployed"> troops
• Order follows eighth night of unrest, teargas and looting
• Brown family attorney: {autopsy showed}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-michael-brown-shot-multiple-times-autopsy-shows-including-in-head"> ‘at least’ six shots
• Curfew defied by protesters and stun grenades shot at crowd
• {Share your photos and videos via GuardianWitness}<hyperlink="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/53f1fea6e4b0f5010eeddaff">

Title: Ferguson crisis: Missouri governor says police will present 'softer front' – live
Author: Tom McCarthy
ArticleText:
Key events

14 Aug 2014: {Nixon calls releasing officer's name 'important milestone'}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting?page=with:block-53ed1c8ce4b038fb92169a6d#block-53ed1c8ce4b038fb92169a6d">

14 Aug 2014: {Nixon removes county police in favor of state patrol}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting?page=with:block-53ed18aee4b0f5010eedd81b#block-53ed18aee4b0f5010eedd81b">

14 Aug 2014: {Callout for reader stories}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting?page=with:block-53ed110ee4b06c461acbb4a1#block-53ed110ee4b06c461acbb4a1">

14 Aug 2014: {Holder: federal investigators have interviewed witnesses}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting?page=with:block-53ed093be4b0d0d62bdb711c#block-53ed093be4b0d0d62bdb711c">

14 Aug 2014: {Holder: these scenes 'cannot continue'}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting?page=with:block-53ed0662e4b0d0d62bdb711a#block-53ed0662e4b0d0d62bdb711a">

14 Aug 2014: {Full text of Obama statement on Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting?page=with:block-53ecfcf4e4b0f5010eedd811#block-53ecfcf4e4b0f5010eedd811">

Live feed

14 Aug 2014 18:02: We’re going to wrap up our live blog coverage for now, possibly to resume later tonight.

We will continue coverage of events in Ferguson on our home page {here.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us"> Jon Swaine is in Ferguson and will file a report later this evening – you can follow Jon on Twitter {@jonswaine.}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/jonswaine">

Here’s a summary of where things stand:

• Protesters began to gather for a fifth night Thursday evening in Ferguson to demand answers in the 9 August police killing of 18-year-old Michael Brown. Police have yet to name the officer involved or to release an incident report.

• Police said they would use a new plan of operation in the streets Thursday night, designed to deescalate confrontations with protesters and encourage dialogue.

• Missouri Governor Jay Nixon announced the state patrol would be taking the lead in the police effort, replacing the St Louis County police department.

• The officer leading tonight’s patrol, Capt. Ron Johnson, said he would be out talking to protesters: “When we talk about boots on the ground, my boots are going to be on the ground.”

• The changes followed a night of clashes Wednesday in which police used rubber bullets and tear gas on peaceful protesters. At least 10 people were arrested Wednesday.

• President Barack Obama took a break from his vacation to address the situation Thursday afternoon. He called on all sides “to take a step back and think about how we’re going to be moving forward.”

•  “There is never an excuse for violence against police,” said Obama. “...There’s also no excuse for police to use excessive force against peaceful protests.”

• Attorney general Eric Holder said federal investigators had interviewed eyewitnesses to the killing of Michael Brown and that a full account of what happened would emerge. The county is conducting a separate probe.

• Saint Louis county executive Charlie Dooley asked people to calm down. “This ought not to be a black and white thing,” he said. “We can do better than this.”

14 Aug 2014 17:31: A picture of the governor and Capt. Johnson’s news conference, via KMOV in St Louis:

[tweetbegin 500014015448629250 tweetend]

14 Aug 2014 17:27: The Guardian’s Jon Swaine is in Ferguson. He reports that Capt. Johnson of the state patrol asked his officers to forgo teargas masks:

[tweetbegin 500023079934775297 tweetend]
[tweetbegin 500021967353692161 tweetend]

14 Aug 2014 17:18: Softer front?

[tweetbegin 500027088536371200 tweetend]

14 Aug 2014 17:08: In a {piece for Comment Is Free,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/14/ferguson-occupation-peace-calm"> Roxane Gay writes that Ferguson is “an occupation happening in plain sight” and a display of police power run amok:

{Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> is the site of an occupation happening in plain sight, and the police remain undeterred because they can occupy, because they know they have unlimited power, because they know they cannot be stopped.
I am stunned but I should not be. I recognize the luxury of my disbelief. I will never allow myself such luxury again. Today, I truly understand privilege.
I am outraged but I do not know what to do with my outrage that might be productive, that might move this world forward toward a place where black lives matter, and where black parents no longer need to {have “the talk” with their children}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/12/mike-brown-ferguson-shooting-police-black"> about how not to be killed by police and where anger over a lifetime of wrongs is not judged, but understood and supported.

Read the {full piece here.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/14/ferguson-occupation-peace-calm">

14 Aug 2014 17:04: The Guardian Jessica Glenza ({@jessicaglenza}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/JessicaGlenza">) has spoken with Missouri Rep Emanuel Cleaver II about the events in Ferguson. Cleaver’s district is across the state in Kansas City, where he used to be mayor.

“Something is wrong in Ferguson, and it didn’t just start with the killing of Michael Brown,” Cleaver said. “It took that killing to bring the light of inadequacy on that community’s leadership.”

Jessica reports:

Asked whether he thought that statements issued by US leaders, including President Obama and Senator Claire McCaskill, were helpful in defusing the situation, Cleaver said, “The president did the right thing, but understand the two things that are still hanging out there that must be dealt with, first of all until the police department or the city prosecutor makes a statement there is going to be this intense suspicion which creates anger.”
As for armored vehicles and other military-style equipment appearing on {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> streets, Cleaver said, “We need to reevaluate distributing this kind of equipment to municipalities. And if we’re going to do it we at least must have other requirements, including something as simple as training.”

“Just think about it – the same equipment we’ve used to fight in Iraq we put on the streets of Ferguson, {Missouri,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/missouri">” Cleaver said. “That’s shameful.”

14 Aug 2014 16:59: The Guardian’s Jon Swaine ({@jonswaine}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/jonswaine">), who attended the news conference with Governor Jay Nixon, flags a key line:

Promising a “softer front”, Nixon said: “Attitudes weren’t improving, and the blocks toward expression appeared to be a flashpoint”.

14 Aug 2014 16:48: Capt Johnson is asked what he will do differently tonight. Will he used armor vehicles and body armor?

“We’re going to go back and assess today,” he says. “When we talk about boots on the ground, my boots are going to be on the ground.”

He says he’ll go to the QuikTrip that burned down and meet with people there himself.

He says they won’t “take resources out there that we don’t need.”

He says they want to “hear people speak... not just let them speak but listening.”

14 Aug 2014 16:47: Nixon is asked about his relationship with the black community. He replies:

“I appreciate the relationship I have with so many friends over so many years in this community... I tremendously appreciate that.
I’m going to continue to not use this as a time to divide... or to see how loud I can talk.
People have first amendment rights, I’ve got executive challenges here.”

He says there should be room for people to publicly disagree.

He’s asked about criticism on Twitter – and one specific criticism apparently involving a “four-letter word”. He replies:

“I try to put gasoline into the engine of fire engines when I see them. Not on the fires. I feel that is more productive.”

14 Aug 2014 16:43: Nixon says the justice department and St Louis County investigations are hustling ahead.

“I think we let them do their jobs. I know they’re hustling their tails off.”

14 Aug 2014 16:41: Nixon is asked how he wants to heal the “deeper wound” he {referred to.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting#block-53ed1dc2e4b038fb92169a6f">

“We’re focused on operational things,” he says. “We’d like to see the danger level go down on a lot of fronts. We’d like to see the investigations that are out there get completed.
It’s really important for people to know what happened and how it happened.”

14 Aug 2014 16:39: Nixon is asked about the problem of persistent racial profiling of black residents of the St Louis area, including traffic stops and other reported harrassment.

Nixon replies that the situation touches a “deeper nerve”:

“This feels a little like an old wound that has been hit again. And so the pain you feel... it feels like a little bit of a longtime simmering. And that I think is natural for all of us to see and to watch.
The key to this is to get control, let voices be heard, make sure we protect property... showing less force on the front side, but ultimately getting to some of these deeper problems.
These are deep and existing problems not only in {Missouri}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/missouri"> but in America... it touches a deeper nerve.
I think ultimately we will be graded or gauged as to whether or not this was an opportunity used to be able to make some longer term understanding..”

14 Aug 2014 16:36: Nixon is asked whether he will look into the arrest and jailing of peaceful protesters Wednesday.

“There’s been gunfire... let’s not kid ourselves folks, this has been a difficult zone.
I think tonight you’ll see... an attempt ... to move forward people and to move back a little bit of equipment.”

14 Aug 2014 16:34: The challenge we face today is not whether we have enough officers or have shown enough strength on the police side, Nixon says.

“We’ve shown that.”

But he says business owners and others would be protected from “illegal acts.”

14 Aug 2014 16:32: Nixon calls releasing officer's name 'important milestone'

Nixon says he doesn’t know the name of the officer who killed Michael Brown.

“I would hold that the appropriate release of that name... would be done as expeditiously as possible” as long as there’s appropriate security, he says.

“I think it would be an important milestone to get that out as expeditiously as possible.”

14 Aug 2014 16:30: Nixon is asked who was in charge of the heavy-handed police presence Wednesday, armor, assault rifles, camo and all.

“That was yesterday. Tonight is tonight. Tomorrow is tomorrow.
Our hope is that this operation shift will begin the process of lowering the intensity of those direct interactions and potential risks... while at the same time allowing people to speak.”

The reporter persists: who was in charge?

“I’m not looking backwards,” Nixon says. “I’m looking forward.”

14 Aug 2014 16:26: Nixon:

“All of us have seen some level of escalation... in terms of the arms that were used as well as some of the conduct.”

He calls for a “dimming” of that escalation.

He says “clearly you’ll see as the afternoon-evening starts, a different picture... Clearly, the strong force on the front line, our hopes would be that we have the ability to get a little more peaceful interaction on the front.”

14 Aug 2014 16:27: Nixon:

“I  think we all have been concerned about the vision that the world has seen about this region. And I think we’re all about making sure that we allow peaceful... protests, that we use force only when necessary, that we step back a little bit and allow some of the energy to be felt in this region appropriately...
I think you’re going to see... I think that while maintaining the peace, but allowing more movement, trying to bring in a different how should we say a different tone of the amplitude of the protective force, my sense is that... people on the ground are working on some of those changes anyway.”

14 Aug 2014 16:25: Slay thanks St Louis County PD officers and others in the streets. “I want to thank you for your service. Thank you for respecting the badge, for honoring your oath.”

14 Aug 2014 16:25: St Louis mayor Francis Slay speaks.

He says Michael Brown’s family, friends, and this community “are all in mourning.”

Slay calls for a full, fair and transparent investigation” and “for justice to be served.”

He says the leaders are in “common agreement”:

“Justice must happen, the grieving must be comforted, the angry must be heard and the innocent must be protected.”

14 Aug 2014 16:22: Saint Louis county executive Charlie Dooley says he’s for justice, not revenge.

He said the community needs to “calm down, stand down and let’s be reasonable. Let’s have a conversation. How do we perceive ourselves? How does the world look at us as a coomunity?

“This ought not to be a black and white thing... we can do better than this.”

14 Aug 2014 16:17: Capt Johnson is speaking.

“I appreciate the significance of this responsibility, he says. “I grew up here, and this is currently my community and my home.”

He says it’s a priority to build trust and maintain communication with residents.

“I understand the anger and fear that the citizens of {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> are feeling, and our police officers will respect both of those,” he says.

14 Aug 2014 16:15: Nixon removes county police in favor of state patrol

Missouri Highway Patrol under Ron Johnson, who grew up in this area, will direct the law enforcement team, Nixon says.

The St Louis County police department is apparently out of the leadership.

14 Aug 2014 16:14: Nixon is speaking. He thanks the University of {Missouri}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/missouri"> St Louis which is hosting the conference.

He says he was briefed this morning and spoke with the president.

He says he has met with faith and civic leaders and visited the scene.

He says he appreciated the opportunity to speak with members of the neighborhood, who said they want peace.

“My message to the people of {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> is that these voices have been heard.
What’s been going on here the last few days is not what Missouri’s about... but lately it’s been more like a war zone.”

14 Aug 2014 16:09: NBC News has a camera on the Nixon news conference, yet to begin:

14 Aug 2014 16:01: The Missouri governor is due to speak soon.

[tweetbegin 500007765126164480 tweetend]

14 Aug 2014 15:50

14 Aug 2014 15:43: Via St. Louis Public Radio:

[tweetbegin 500003129631735809 tweetend]

14 Aug 2014 15:42: Callout for reader stories

[Reposted from this morning]

{The St Louis Post-Dispatch editorial page}<hyperlink="http://www.stltoday.com/news/opinion/"> and the the Guardian US opinion page have launched a joint project to collect readers’ stories about the relationship in their communities between residents and law enforcement.

{Contribute to this story by clicking here.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/13/michael-brown-shooting-police-racial-profiling-ferguson"> What is your police racial profiling story? How did it change you? If you’re from Ferguson or the St Louis region, tell the world the real story, from on the ground, that you think needs to be told – and what needs to change. Your submissions could be used for special Post-Dispatch / Guardian interactive features as the story unfolds.

14 Aug 2014 15:30: The St Louis Riverfront Times has {published a list}<hyperlink="http://blogs.riverfronttimes.com/dailyrft/2014/08/7_peaceful_ways_to_respond_to_michael_browns_death_ferguson_unrest.php"> of “7 Peaceful Ways to Respond to Michael Brown’s Death, Ferguson Unrest”. Here’s No.4:

4. Sign the petition for the “Michael Brown Law.”
More than 1,000 people have already {signed a petition demanding that police officers}<hyperlink="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.change.org%2Fpetitions%2Fst-louis-county-and-city-create-a-michael-brown-law-requiring-police-officers-to-wear-cameras-and-record-any-interaction-with-the-public-at-all-times%3Frecruiter%3D572265%26utm_campaign%3Dshare_facebook_mobile%26utm_medium%3Dfacebook%26utm_source%3Dshare_petition&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNHBNZCZayE72dre3WCQyzZxCudlbA"> to wear cameras at all times. Police in Columbia have been {wearing body cameras}<hyperlink="http://www.columbiatribune.com/news/crime/all-uniformed-police-officers-to-be-equipped-with-body-cameras/article_26c7191c-a024-5e84-97e7-6bfb4347fcc0.html?comments=focus"> since last month.
Update: Here’s a similar petition with 116,000+ signatures: {Please Enact New Federal Laws to Protect Citizens from Police Violence and Misconduct.}<hyperlink="http://www.change.org/petitions/president-barack-obama-please-enact-new-federal-laws-to-protect-citizens-from-police-violence-and-misconduct?share_id=tsaboYqTkZ&utm_campaign=friend_inviter_chat&utm_medium=facebook&utm_source=share_petition&utm_term=permissions_dialog_false">

Read the {full list here.}<hyperlink="http://blogs.riverfronttimes.com/dailyrft/2014/08/7_peaceful_ways_to_respond_to_michael_browns_death_ferguson_unrest.php">

14 Aug 2014 15:27: A Democratic congressman plans to introduce a bill to restrict a Defense Department program that provides machine guns and other surplus military equipment for free to local law enforcement agencies across the US, the AP reports:

Rep. Hank Johnson said the legislation is in response to the death of an unarmed teenager who was shot by a police officer in a St. Louis suburb.
Johnson said city streets should be a place for businesses and families, “not tanks and M16s.” He said a Pentagon program that transfers surplus military equipment to state and local law enforcement has led to police agencies resembling paramilitary forces.
“Militarizing America’s main streets won’t make us any safer, just more fearful and more reticent,” Johnson said. He said his bill would limit the type of military equipment that can be transferred to law enforcement, and require states to certify they can account for all equipment received.

14 Aug 2014 15:10: Holder: federal investigators have interviewed witnesses

Federal investigators have “already conducted interviews with eyewitnesses on the scene at the time of the shooting incident on Saturday,” attorney general Holder said at the end of his {statement}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/aug/14/erguson-protests-police-crackdown-michael-brown-shooting#block-53ed0662e4b0d0d62bdb711a"> Thursday.

Those investigators come from the civil rights division of the department of justice and the U.S. attorney’s office in {Missouri.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/missouri">

“Our review will take time to conduct, but it will be thorough and fair,” Holder said.

14 Aug 2014 15:05: A defense department spokesman said a program to give secondhand military gear to local law enforcement was “useful” and prevented waste.

Here are remarks by Rear Adm. John Kirby, the Pentagon press secretary, via Guardian national security editor Spencer Ackerman ({@attackerman}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/attackerman">):

“There is a law enforcement support program that the Defense Department administers which provides to law enforcement agencies around the country surplus military equipment, gear, arms, ammunition, vehicles. This is a useful program that allows for the re-use of military equipment that otherwise would be disposed of that can be used again by law enforcement agencies to serve their citizens. The program serves a purpose.
“That said, it is up to law enforcement agencies to speak to how and what they gain through this system, and I’m not going to inject the Pentagon into this discussion. How this equipment is used to serve local citizens is up for local law enforcement agencies to speak to.”

14 Aug 2014 14:59: Holder: these scenes 'cannot continue'

Attorney General Eric Holder {released}<hyperlink="http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2014/August/14-ag-854.html"> a statement Thursday following his meeting with President Obama to discuss the latest developments in Ferguson:

“This morning, I met with President Obama to discuss the events in Ferguson, Missouri. Like the President, I extend my heartfelt condolences to the family of Michael Brown. While his death has understandably caused heartache within the community, it is clear that the scenes playing out in the streets of {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> over the last several nights cannot continue.
“For one thing, while the vast majority of protests have been peaceful, acts of violence by members of the public cannot be condoned. Looting and willful efforts to antagonize law enforcement officers who are genuinely trying to protect the public do nothing to remember the young man who has died. Such conduct is unacceptable and must be unequivocally condemned.
“By the same token, the law enforcement response to these demonstrations must seek to reduce tensions, not heighten them. Those who peacefully gather to express sympathy for the family of Michael Brown must have their rights respected at all times. And journalists must not be harassed or prevented from covering a story that needs to be told.
“At a time when we must seek to rebuild trust between law enforcement and the local community, I am deeply concerned that the deployment of military equipment and vehicles sends a conflicting message. At my direction, Department officials have conveyed these concerns to local authorities. Also at my direction, the Department is offering – through our COPS office and Office of Justice Programs – technical assistance to local authorities in order to help conduct crowd control and maintain public safety without relying on unnecessarily extreme displays of force. Here is President Barack Obama’s statement on {Ferguson}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> in full, via the White House press shop:

“Now, second, I want to address something that’s been in the news over the last couple of days and that’s the situation in Ferguson, {Missouri.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/missouri"> I know that many Americans have been deeply disturbed by the images we’ve seen in the heartland of our country, as police have clashed with people protesting. “This morning, I received a thorough update on the situation from Attorney General Eric Holder, who has been following it and been in communication with his team. I’ve already tasked the Department of Justice and the FBI to independently investigate the death of Michael Brown, along with local officials on the ground.
“The Department of Justice is also consulting with local authorities about ways that they can maintain public safety without restricting the right of peaceful protest and while avoiding unnecessary escalation. I made clear to the Attorney General that we should do what is necessary to help determine exactly what happened, and to see that justice is done.
“I also just spoke with Governor Jay Nixon of Missouri. I expressed my concern over the violent turn that events have taken on the ground, and underscored that now is the time for all of us to reflect on what’s happened, and to find a way to come together going forward. He is going to be traveling to Ferguson. He is a good man and a fine governor, and I’m confident that, working together, he is going to be able to communicate his desire to make sure that justice is done and his desire to make sure that public safety is maintained in an appropriate way.
“Of course, it’s important to remember how this started. We lost a young man, Michael Brown, in heartbreaking and tragic circumstances. He was 18 years old. His family will never hold Michael in their arms again. And when something like this happens, the local authorities –- including the police -– have a responsibility to be open and transparent about how they are investigating that death, and how they are protecting the people in their communities.
“There is never an excuse for violence against police, or for those who would use this tragedy as a cover for vandalism or looting. And here, in the United States of America, police should not be bullying or arresting journalists who are just trying to do their jobs and report to the American people on what they see on the ground. “I know that emotions are raw right now in Ferguson and there are certainly passionate differences about what has happened. There are going to be different accounts of how this tragedy occurred. There are going to be differences in terms of what needs to happen going forward. That’s part of our democracy. But let’s remember that we’re all part of one American family. We are united in common values, and that includes belief in equality under the law; a basic respect for public order and the right to peaceful public protest; a reverence for the dignity of every single man, woman and child among us; and the need for accountability when it comes to our government.
“So now is the time for healing. Now is the time for peace and calm on the streets of Ferguson. Now is the time for an open and transparent process to see that justice is done. And I’ve asked that the Attorney General and the U.S. Attorney on the scene continue to work with local officials to move that process forward. They will be reporting to me in the coming days about what’s being done to make sure that happens.”

The White House said early on Thursday that Barack Obama had interrupted his vacation on Martha’s Vineyard, Massachusetts, to be briefed by the US attorney general, Eric Holder, on the situation.

On Wednesday, Swaine {witnessed}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/14/ferguson-police-arrest-reporters-as-unrest-continues-over-michael-brown-shooting"> the arrest of two reporters who had been sitting at work inside a McDonalds, including one from the Washington Post. Marty Baron, the Post’s editor, condemned the arrest as “an assault on the freedom of the press to cover the news.”

Ferguson, a {city of 21,000,}<hyperlink="http://www.fergusoncity.com/"> is attached to St Louis, which has a metropolitan area of almost 3m residents. St Louis County police are leading the law enforcement response.

Brian Schellman, a spokesman for the county police, told the Guardian at the law enforcement command centre late on Wednesday that chiefs would review tactics after the night’s events.

We’ll be running the live blog throughout the day to follow the latest events in {Ferguson,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ferguson"> and the reaction to them.

Title: Hands up: the message from Ferguson – in pictures
Author: NA
ArticleText: NA
TheShitBetween: There is a weird alchemy that takes place during the construction of a perfect protest sign; the recipe changes according to the circumstances. The shooting and killing of ­unarmed black teenager Mike Brown by police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, Missouri, has brought forth an eloquent crop. Some are very specific: “Hands Up, Don’t Shoot”, reads one sign, a paraphrase of Brown’s alleged last words. While Brown’s loss is unique to his family, the horrific narrative – unarmed black person killed by white law enforcement figure – is one that black Americans know all too well. One sign lists the names of other unarmed black men and women killed in similar circumstances. The list is so long that one sign is ­incredulous: “I can’t believe I still have to ­protest this shit”. Indeed.

Title: Donald Glover Q&A – post your questions now!
Author: Guardian music
ArticleText:
Key events

18 Aug 2014: {This webchat has been cancelled}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/music/live/2014/aug/15/donald-glover-childish-gambino-post-your-questions-webchat?page=with:block-53f20ebbe4b038fb92169cbe#block-53f20ebbe4b038fb92169cbe">

Live feed

18 Aug 2014 10:40: This webchat has been cancelled

Our apologies, but Donald Glover has cancelled all of his UK press during his tour. He gave us a single-word reason:

#ferguson

Glover has been outspoken during the {current unrest in Ferguson,}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/18/ferguson-missouri-michael-brown-national-guard-deployed"> posting {a series of tweets}<hyperlink="https://twitter.com/donaldglover"> denouncing “Twitter activism”, as well as a multi-tweet poem in which he wryly wishes he was white. He also tweeted that “I’ve been threatened by police twice this year.”

We hope to reschedule the webchat for some point in the future – in the meantime, thanks to everyone who posted a question.

15 Aug 2014 10:05: Post your questions for Donald Glover

Looking at Donald Glover’s CV will make you feel tired and unspectacular.

His primary creative outlet at the moment is rapping as Childish Gambino, with his recent album Because the Internet pairing a perfectly balanced flow with psychedelically futurist production (it also had {a gif for an album cover,}<hyperlink="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Childish-gambino-because-the-internet.gif"> Tumblr fans). He’s also appeared on tracks with stadium dubstep producer Flux Pavilion, fellow internet master Riff Raff, and new-school R&B star Jhene Aiko, in {a video}<hyperlink="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UoIpx1ZxFeM"> that riffs on John and Yoko’s bed-ins.

But he’s also known for his acting, having traded saliva and racial politics with Lena Dunham in Girls, and been a central character in five seasons of cult sitcom {Community.}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/community"> He started out as a writer for 30 Rock, and he’s signed up to write and star in Atlanta, a new comedy show set against the backdrop of the city he grew up in. He also created a feature length film with his sketch comedy troupe Mystery Team.

Then there’s his standup. Comedy aficionados should check out Weirdo, his excellent hour-long special for {Comedy}<hyperlink="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/comedy"> Central in which he tackles defecation, sugar addiction, and erotic power of the n-word, his voice bouncing elastically between different personae throughout.

He plays as Childish Gambino at London’s Brixton Academy on Tuesday 19 September – and is also coming in to answer your questions that very same day, from 1-2pm. So what do you want to ask him? Post your questions below and he’ll endeavour to answer as many as possible.
TheShitBetween: He’s the pop-cultural polymath who raps as Childish Gambino, has acted in Community and Girls, and has a sideline in deft standup comedy. Donald Glover is set to answer your questions on Tuesday 19 August from 1pm onwards – so what do you want to ask him?
